headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just a kind of follow-up on that last - one of the last questions around the EMG revenue. At some quarters back in fiscal ’08, you were over $900 million revenue quarter. Do you see that as kind of achievable over the next cycle or has anything c
componenttext: First, just a kind of follow-up on that last - one of the last questions around the EMG revenue. At some quarters back in fiscal ’08, you were over $900 million revenue quarter. Do you see that as kind of achievable over the next cycle or has anything changed fundamentally in the business on your position that might make up more difficult?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We - and I have Ron make a comment. We divested our Network business, and so we have a part of the market that we no longer participate in. So you would have to discount the high point of our networking business. But if we are successful in our product st
componenttext: We - and I have Ron make a comment. We divested our Network business, and so we have a part of the market that we no longer participate in. So you would have to discount the high point of our networking business. But if we are successful in our product strategy, successful in each of these segments, there is no reason why we could not move back to our historic position in all of these product lines.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that’s exactly correct. The only addition I would make is that we are shifting away from going after some business in manufacturing that has very low gross margins and low probability in placing more of our portfolio in R&D. So that is why
componenttext: Yes, I think that’s exactly correct. The only addition I would make is that we are shifting away from going after some business in manufacturing that has very low gross margins and low probability in placing more of our portfolio in R&D. So that is why you are seeing very, very high gross margins of 59% for EMG and 18% operating profit even at this level of revenue, slightly below $700 million. So it’s not just the revenue line, but our earnings potential is much greater as we shift the mix of our portfolio.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because it seems clear that you believe we are not at or very close to a peak in that business. Can you give us an update on the distribution strategy? I understand that this part of the restructuring in EMG, you adopted a bit more of an indirect selling
componenttext: Because it seems clear that you believe we are not at or very close to a peak in that business. Can you give us an update on the distribution strategy? I understand that this part of the restructuring in EMG, you adopted a bit more of an indirect selling strategy. Can you update us on that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Overall, our primary channel to go the market is our direct sales strategy. But clearly, with our direct sales, we cannot go ahead and get all of the reach that we want. So we’re working very effectively with many partners. And accordingly in the
componenttext: Sure. Overall, our primary channel to go the market is our direct sales strategy. But clearly, with our direct sales, we cannot go ahead and get all of the reach that we want. So we’re working very effectively with many partners. And accordingly in the last year, we’ve taken the percentage of our sales and distribution from roughly 9% to about 18%. So twice as much of our business on a percentage basis is going through distribution. If you look at it on a dollar basis, our indirect sales were up 89% this last quarter. And that’s why you see great growth in product lines such as oscilloscope. So oscilloscope order growth restated the revenue growth of 45%, but oscilloscope order growth was over 50%. And that’s because of the great high performance products that were introduced in April, but also because of the lower end scopes that are sold through distribution. So the distribution strategy is working exceptionally well. We have doubled the percentage of business - of our business that goes through distribution, and we plan to continue to go much, much further with that, as we continue to execute our strategy.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And then one short follow-up if I can, any impact from supply chain issues like component shortages, which referred so much about from other companies this quarter?
componenttext: Great. And then one short follow-up if I can, any impact from supply chain issues like component shortages, which referred so much about from other companies this quarter?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have had part shortages across almost every one of our product lines. Again, this is an issue in the industry. Actually some of the Varian product lines have been impacted even more than some of our product lines in Life Science, for example, or in Ron
componenttext: We have had part shortages across almost every one of our product lines. Again, this is an issue in the industry. Actually some of the Varian product lines have been impacted even more than some of our product lines in Life Science, for example, or in Ron’s business in EMG. The team continues to do a great job of trying to expedite parts moving forward, but it has had a negative impact on our ability to turn these very robust orders into revenue. We will continue to catch up as we move forward in Q4, but we have not been immune to the part shortages.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill.
componenttext: Thanks, Bill.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Groberg with Macquarie. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Groberg with Macquarie. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thanks for taking my questions. Just two questions. First one, could you maybe talk any more specifically I guess around Varian? And your first priority was to stabilize the orders there. You have - can you just talk about how that’s gone since the
componenttext: Hi. Thanks for taking my questions. Just two questions. First one, could you maybe talk any more specifically I guess around Varian? And your first priority was to stabilize the orders there. You have - can you just talk about how that’s gone since the acquisition is closed?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. And again, both Mike and Nick, make a comment. But the team has done, I think, just an extraordinary job of integrating the Varian sales team into ours very, very quickly. We have put programs in place. We have put to - in fact it’s to drive orde
componenttext: Right. And again, both Mike and Nick, make a comment. But the team has done, I think, just an extraordinary job of integrating the Varian sales team into ours very, very quickly. We have put programs in place. We have put to - in fact it’s to drive order lead generation. We have put together an extensive training program to ensure that Agilent employees, our salespeople can sell Varian products. And so again, we’re early into this, but from my perspective, we have made enormous progress, which is typically the most difficult part of the process as to integrate the sales organization. Mike, Nick, any additional comments?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill, I could just build on your comments. We’re really focusing, Jonathan, on driving that leverage from the combined sales force. As Bill mentioned, we have some programs we’ve put in place that already are leading - delivering significant amou
componenttext: Yes, Bill, I could just build on your comments. We’re really focusing, Jonathan, on driving that leverage from the combined sales force. As Bill mentioned, we have some programs we’ve put in place that already are leading - delivering significant amounts in incremental leads and that should close in some new business. So really pleased with how the customers respond to the combined portfolio and this combined sales force effort really is yielding us results we hoped when we first went down this path.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Nick. I’ll just ski [ph] off Mike’s comments. 80 days in, we’ve turned that focus, as Mike just pointed, to - we've got the internal stuff pretty well along. We’re working with the external stuff and our fixing customer communications and
componenttext: This is Nick. I’ll just ski [ph] off Mike’s comments. 80 days in, we’ve turned that focus, as Mike just pointed, to - we've got the internal stuff pretty well along. We’re working with the external stuff and our fixing customer communications and fixing service. And we’re really here to stay. We’re going to put the investment and customers are starting to see it.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just one kind of clarification, you guys - you gave some view on what revenues would be for the year with Varian. Any change to that?
componenttext: And just one kind of clarification, you guys - you gave some view on what revenues would be for the year with Varian. Any change to that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ask the question again in terms of -
componenttext: Ask the question again in terms of -

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: You said you thought Varian would add about $370 million in revenues once it closed for the year. I was just curious if there was any change in that.
componenttext: You said you thought Varian would add about $370 million in revenues once it closed for the year. I was just curious if there was any change in that.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think right now - I mean, the total number - because of the old Agilent products, we are in very, very strong position. Because of the part shortages, I think that the revenue number will come in roughly $20 million shorter on the Varian side than we an
componenttext: I think right now - I mean, the total number - because of the old Agilent products, we are in very, very strong position. Because of the part shortages, I think that the revenue number will come in roughly $20 million shorter on the Varian side than we anticipated. No material impact in total, but that is happening just because of part shortages. And I think there is about another $10 million of revenue that’s being absorbed into the Agilent product lines. As we notified customers of how we are going to merge some of the overlapping product lines that were not divested. And so I think that there will be some smaller impact, but again as we regain the order momentum to the programs that Mike and Nick talked about, I think that we’re going to easily offset the $20 million moving forward into FY ’11. Secondly, we restively are putting in people and teams to try to expedite the parts coming in so that we can catch up on our backlog.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you - obviously you said that the business remains very robust. Just curious if you can - if you can, if there is any detail to add, talk a little bit about Electronic Measurement, but maybe more on the Life Science, Chemical Analysis s
componenttext: Okay. And then can you - obviously you said that the business remains very robust. Just curious if you can - if you can, if there is any detail to add, talk a little bit about Electronic Measurement, but maybe more on the Life Science, Chemical Analysis side in terms of what you saw specifically maybe in July towards the end of last quarter. And some other life science companies were saying they started to see some things slow in Europe in particular, and maybe a little bit in the US. So just I guess curious what you guys saw as you exited your quarter.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you can see by our numbers, our organic growth rate in both Chemical Analysis and Life Science is very robust. But I’ll have Mike and Nick give their color commentary in terms of any trends. But again, we had a strong quarter.
componenttext: As you can see by our numbers, our organic growth rate in both Chemical Analysis and Life Science is very robust. But I’ll have Mike and Nick give their color commentary in terms of any trends. But again, we had a strong quarter.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’ll go first. This is Nick. It’s a good comment. So we had double-digit growth across all regions in Life Science, with Europe doing about 13%. So we haven’t seen any softness in Europe, and we’ve built backlog for a range of reasons, including t
componenttext: I’ll go first. This is Nick. It’s a good comment. So we had double-digit growth across all regions in Life Science, with Europe doing about 13%. So we haven’t seen any softness in Europe, and we’ve built backlog for a range of reasons, including the parts issues of unintentional. So we are in a pretty strong position. We’re not seeing slowdowns. And if anything, we keep commenting about pharma. It has moved into positive growth territory, including Europe. So while it’s soft and it’s coming back slow, we are seeing real growth come back across the board. So whatever weakness is out there, it may be in sectors that we don’t touch as strongly like the academic in Europe where we’re not as big a player.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, similar message on the Chemical Analysis side, continued strong recovery in both America and Europe and the continuation of the Asia growth story for us.
componenttext: Jonathan, similar message on the Chemical Analysis side, continued strong recovery in both America and Europe and the continuation of the Asia growth story for us.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Congratulations. Thanks.
componenttext: Okay. Congratulations. Thanks.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Butler, Barclays Capital. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Butler, Barclays Capital. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much. Couple of questions. One, again to Varian, can you - something new to Agilent, so obviously NMR. Is that where you’re having parts shortages? Moreover, are you having increasing demand there now that you are able to consolidate sales f
componenttext: Thanks very much. Couple of questions. One, again to Varian, can you - something new to Agilent, so obviously NMR. Is that where you’re having parts shortages? Moreover, are you having increasing demand there now that you are able to consolidate sales force and actually push that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The part shortages across the board - number one part shortages is Electronic Measurement, it’s got the highest growth. Secondly, I would say, it would be Varian. Third one would be in the Life Science area. But I’m going to have both Mike and then Ni
componenttext: The part shortages across the board - number one part shortages is Electronic Measurement, it’s got the highest growth. Secondly, I would say, it would be Varian. Third one would be in the Life Science area. But I’m going to have both Mike and then Nick comment about the product portfolios. As I said in my comment, we are committed to - and we are not sure when this will happen, but we will drive to become number one in spectroscopy as well as in NMR, and we are taking actions to do that. But Mike, why don’t you make a few comments? And then, Nick, about what you’re seeing with the product portfolio that has come into the company?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about the three product categories. First, as Bill mentioned, the drive in spectroscopy are drive to be number one. We are seeing already leverage from the combined sales force generating increased demand. And we plan stepped up R&D investment
componenttext: Let me talk about the three product categories. First, as Bill mentioned, the drive in spectroscopy are drive to be number one. We are seeing already leverage from the combined sales force generating increased demand. And we plan stepped up R&D investments and continue to enhance our portfolio. So, good news there. We have not talked about this in this call today, but the consumable is also a very big bright spot for us. We now have three additional divisions that have been consolidated into our consumables business. And already the new Agilent sales force is selling the sample prep products from the Varian portfolio. So, getting good solid growth there. And then the vacuum business, which we’ve not talked a lot about today as well, up 34% over last year and a nice recovery mode as well.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And (inaudible). Research products is a pretty broad portfolio. NMR is the big business in there. It’s still early. These are long cycle developments and long cycle orders. So our commitment to R&D in that sector is really resonating with customers. We
componenttext: And (inaudible). Research products is a pretty broad portfolio. NMR is the big business in there. It’s still early. These are long cycle developments and long cycle orders. So our commitment to R&D in that sector is really resonating with customers. We are seeing some real funnel growth and some actual order growth. But at this point, the order cycle is so long that I can’t claim any victories there.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And the last question is around LC. I know it was up 25% I think. Comments were made around not only 1290 but the mid-range LC products. Is this the result of commitments for new orders or is it replacement orders? Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you. And the last question is around LC. I know it was up 25% I think. Comments were made around not only 1290 but the mid-range LC products. Is this the result of commitments for new orders or is it replacement orders? Thank you.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s really the whole spectrum, Tony. We are seeing everything across the board. But it’s just a really strong product in the 1290. We follow it up with new members of that family at the midrange and low end. So now we’ve got the most modern portfol
componenttext: It’s really the whole spectrum, Tony. We are seeing everything across the board. But it’s just a really strong product in the 1290. We follow it up with new members of that family at the midrange and low end. So now we’ve got the most modern portfolio across the entire range. And as you can see, we are doing very well, but we are getting a lot of growth out of the applied markets as well. And those markets are places where there is new market creation. So we’re really proud of that 25% growth.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot.
componenttext: Thanks a lot.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Bill, could you just talk for a second - within the EMG group business, Europe was up 18%. And could you just kind of explain maybe that number a little bit? And are we seeing maybe a fundamental upshift in R&D spend or are we really seein
componenttext: Good afternoon. Bill, could you just talk for a second - within the EMG group business, Europe was up 18%. And could you just kind of explain maybe that number a little bit? And are we seeing maybe a fundamental upshift in R&D spend or are we really seeing a bounce from last year? Because 18% out of Europe these days is a pretty impressive number.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again I will - this quarter I’ve spent a lot of time bragging about the great product portfolio that we have. And I can’t stress enough the transformation the company has gone through moving forward. But I have Ron comment about Europe specifically, a
componenttext: Again I will - this quarter I’ve spent a lot of time bragging about the great product portfolio that we have. And I can’t stress enough the transformation the company has gone through moving forward. But I have Ron comment about Europe specifically, again given how strong our growth was. Go ahead, Ron.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Although Americas and Europe, both had 18% revenue growth, Europe actually outgrew the Americas with 24% order growth. So we’re seeing very solid results in Europe. And as Bill had mentioned earlier, we haven’t seen any signs of a downturn at al
componenttext: Sure. Although Americas and Europe, both had 18% revenue growth, Europe actually outgrew the Americas with 24% order growth. So we’re seeing very solid results in Europe. And as Bill had mentioned earlier, we haven’t seen any signs of a downturn at all. Matter of fact, the orders are very, very robust across the board. So the business that is there, there is some manufacturing in Europe, but there is obviously a lot of wireless R&D that we play in. And we play across the overall wireless food chain as well as in the general electronics and communication space. So the short answer is, we haven’t seen a slowdown. The growth in Europe actually even outpaced the Americas.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there any leadership there in Europe on the LTE side that they maybe jumped to a bit of a leadership in terms of not only development but deployment? Or is that not a big factor in that growth rate?
componenttext: Is there any leadership there in Europe on the LTE side that they maybe jumped to a bit of a leadership in terms of not only development but deployment? Or is that not a big factor in that growth rate?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s not a big factor in the growth rate. You have more R&D for wireless handsets and reference design houses in Europe, but there is even more of a shift of that over to Asia. So if you are looking for a shift in the balance of the players by regions
componenttext: That’s not a big factor in the growth rate. You have more R&D for wireless handsets and reference design houses in Europe, but there is even more of a shift of that over to Asia. So if you are looking for a shift in the balance of the players by regions, China is actually starting to grow more and more. And they are implementing their version of LTE called TD-LTE, which will probably be adopted in India as well. But that - it's pretty much across the board. Our oscilloscope products are also are very strong. Our network analyzer products, as Bill mentioned, and we are seeing good strong order growth from all of our product lines at this time.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one follow-up maybe for Didier. When you talked about some preliminary thoughts about fiscal ’11 in that forecast, obviously scenario - the difference between scenario one and two was just that core growth - organic growth assumption
componenttext: Okay. And then just one follow-up maybe for Didier. When you talked about some preliminary thoughts about fiscal ’11 in that forecast, obviously scenario - the difference between scenario one and two was just that core growth - organic growth assumption. And I’m curious, given - let’s just say the three parts of the business between CA, LS and EMG, is the difference in that core growth rate, is it primarily the assumption that you are using on EMG? In other words, is LC or CA and LS, are they pretty much static growth in both of those scenarios?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: They are more comparable in EM. In both scenarios, we are assuming lower growth than within the bad markets rather than -
componenttext: They are more comparable in EM. In both scenarios, we are assuming lower growth than within the bad markets rather than -

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the first scenario, we are assuming approximately 7% growth for EMG, which corresponds to the SIA index and where it’s expected to be for next year at 6.3% with minor share gains, and again, a much - that's a relatively conservative number compa
componenttext: Yes. In the first scenario, we are assuming approximately 7% growth for EMG, which corresponds to the SIA index and where it’s expected to be for next year at 6.3% with minor share gains, and again, a much - that's a relatively conservative number compared to this year. In the second scenario, we are closer to flat. And the primary sector or some segment of that is the semiconductor business where we have modest growth in the first scenario. And in the second scenario, we could withstand approximately a 45% decline in the semiconductor segment and still deliver the second scenario.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it annualized run rate there? We’re talking about maybe $160 million in revenue, I mean, just off of a third quarter performance just to size it?
componenttext: Is it annualized run rate there? We’re talking about maybe $160 million in revenue, I mean, just off of a third quarter performance just to size it?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ask the question again, please.
componenttext: Ask the question again, please.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at the semiconductor revenue in the third quarter of this year just completed, if you were to annualize that number, what is the order magnitude of the revenue right now?
componenttext: Looking at the semiconductor revenue in the third quarter of this year just completed, if you were to annualize that number, what is the order magnitude of the revenue right now?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are not reporting that number. There is different parts of our business that actually plan into the semiconductor business, direct products such as our parametric test products and then other products that -
componenttext: We are not reporting that number. There is different parts of our business that actually plan into the semiconductor business, direct products such as our parametric test products and then other products that -

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s going to be - so much of our investment in semi would go into the chip design. And again we have a strong position in our scopes and we have - the whole PCI express moving. I think it’s fair, Ron, that in terms of stuff that is tied, we still hav
componenttext: It’s going to be - so much of our investment in semi would go into the chip design. And again we have a strong position in our scopes and we have - the whole PCI express moving. I think it’s fair, Ron, that in terms of stuff that is tied, we still have a small business tied directly IC cap and that’s probably in the $100 million that you’re talking about. So it’s not very large. So if you assume an organic growth rate, let’s say, normally of 7, you get to 9 with a stronger EMG, little bit below that with a weaker EMG. That’s how I would characterize it. And as simple as that, and obviously we will nail this down next month and report it in our guidance moving forward. But that’s how I look at it 7 plus or minus a couple, borrowing a major downturn.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Very good. Thank you.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Douglass with Longbow Research. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon.
componenttext: Hi, good afternoon.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hello.
componenttext: Hello.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Didier.
componenttext: Congratulations, Didier.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the - if we go back to EMG, any adjustments right now to your expectations for mid-cycle margins, I mean, versus your latest in the mid-cycle target you gave earlier this year? I mean, you are not in mid-cycle yet, but you are already 18%. How should w
componenttext: On the - if we go back to EMG, any adjustments right now to your expectations for mid-cycle margins, I mean, versus your latest in the mid-cycle target you gave earlier this year? I mean, you are not in mid-cycle yet, but you are already 18%. How should we think about that going forward?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Ron is going to do really well. So I’ll let him answer the question.
componenttext: I think Ron is going to do really well. So I’ll let him answer the question.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we mentioned earlier, operating margin at this point is at 18%. And we talked about at a $600 million per quarter run rate or $2.4 billion bottom or trial that we would produce 12% operating margin and 21% at the peak. We are clearly well above the mid
componenttext: As we mentioned earlier, operating margin at this point is at 18%. And we talked about at a $600 million per quarter run rate or $2.4 billion bottom or trial that we would produce 12% operating margin and 21% at the peak. We are clearly well above the midpoint right now, and our margins continue to be healthy. And our guidance will reflect what we think we can deliver in EM.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have spoken about this. The transformation of EMG has just been dramatic and won’t take much for Ron to get over 20% operating profit depending on the recovery. You couple that with two other parts of the business that historically have been growing
componenttext: We have spoken about this. The transformation of EMG has just been dramatic and won’t take much for Ron to get over 20% operating profit depending on the recovery. You couple that with two other parts of the business that historically have been growing substantially above the organic growth rate of the market. It’s just a great combination. And again, another plug-in for EMG. This is by the first quarter that we believe that the organic growth rate was higher than the market. And so Ron’s transformation is done. Got a great product portfolio moving forward. And you couple that with the Varian acquisition and the continued strong position of our Chemical business and Life Science business, I think that we are very well positioned moving into 2011.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And then, Ron, also on your lower priced o-scopes, the sell-through for that, is that matching your expectation, exceeding your expectation? Do you pretty much believe you are getting some share gains there?
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then, Ron, also on your lower priced o-scopes, the sell-through for that, is that matching your expectation, exceeding your expectation? Do you pretty much believe you are getting some share gains there?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are pretty sure that we are getting share gains and again with over 50% order growth. And when we look at the sell-through working with distributors, we feel very confident that we are taking share in that space. And again, the 45% revenue growth was b
componenttext: We are pretty sure that we are getting share gains and again with over 50% order growth. And when we look at the sell-through working with distributors, we feel very confident that we are taking share in that space. And again, the 45% revenue growth was basically supply limited, or we could have delivered even more than that. But we feel really confident that we are taking share and we’re penetrating areas where Tektronix used to play as our lower end product line and mid-range product line as more competitive. And at the high end, we have the world’s highest performance, real-time bandwidth that really is a very, very large deal for our leading edge customers. So we’re very, very pleased with our overall oscilloscope product line. And again, we’ve grown faster in the oscilloscope product line over the last eight years than any other player in the industry, and we’re excited to see the share gain we will continue to get.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one final question, is there a possibility of a modular hardware release anytime in the near term? If so, when are you thinking about that?
componenttext: And one final question, is there a possibility of a modular hardware release anytime in the near term? If so, when are you thinking about that?

And just follow up on the last question, revenue tells you a little bit about what’s going on in the markets. If you’re looking for the slow - if there is a slowdown or not, orders is even more timely. Our orders for EMG in Japan were up 69% this last quarter.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And for the company overall, orders were up 45% on an organic basis.
componenttext: And for the company overall, orders were up 45% on an organic basis.

componenttext: Why do you think that is occurring?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are seeing some investment in LTE in Japan. They are planned to launch in 2010. There is a lot of spending right now on base stations. And Japan is providing a lot of components to feed into the China market. So the success in Japan is not necessarily
componenttext: We are seeing some investment in LTE in Japan. They are planned to launch in 2010. There is a lot of spending right now on base stations. And Japan is providing a lot of components to feed into the China market. So the success in Japan is not necessarily just about the Japanese end market, but it’s really about China. And as we talked about, our China growth is very strong at over 60% for EMG.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Quite honestly, I wish that Agilent could have an impact on the world’s gross domestic product overall moving forward. And that’s why it’s so important for us to focus on investment where the money is, where people need measurement tools. And I
componenttext: Yes. Quite honestly, I wish that Agilent could have an impact on the world’s gross domestic product overall moving forward. And that’s why it’s so important for us to focus on investment where the money is, where people need measurement tools. And I think some of the numbers that we are sharing with you today is indicative of our ability to have the right products for the market needs. Again, this recovery is very, very fragmented. You really need to go into each one of these market segments to really understand what’s going on. And fortunately, we don’t make any measurement solutions for the construction industry, as an example, for that. But our overall assumption in Europe is that the gross domestic product will grow in the plus-1% range.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just wanted to visit your operating margin for the overall company. I think you’ve had a record sort of third quarter operating margin this time and materially lower revenues. I think you’ve attributed some of that to a mix shift and be on the EM
componenttext: Yes. Just wanted to visit your operating margin for the overall company. I think you’ve had a record sort of third quarter operating margin this time and materially lower revenues. I think you’ve attributed some of that to a mix shift and be on the EMG side. But your margins right now are still below your targets in EMG for peak targets. And also for - when you look at your Chemical Analysis and Life Science margins, on an operating side, they are significantly lower than what you have delivered in the recent past, in ’08. So from a broad perspective, where do you expect your operating margins to go over the next couple of years, how much higher, and on what level of revenue?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The operating models for Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences are being impacted with the Varian acquisition. The gross margin difference between Varian and ourselves are 10 points. And we are fully committed to make up that difference. And that’s why w
componenttext: The operating models for Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences are being impacted with the Varian acquisition. The gross margin difference between Varian and ourselves are 10 points. And we are fully committed to make up that difference. And that’s why we are so confident that we will be able to drive that $75 million of net savings moving forward. In terms of the margins for Electronic Measurement, confused on your question because both the gross margin and the operating profit in Electronic Measurement are close to record highs.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. And how much higher can they go on the Electronic Measurement side? And also on Varian - yes, I mean, that’s the reason why the operating margins have been impacted. But how much time do you think it’s going to take? And can that entire Varian
componenttext: Right. And how much higher can they go on the Electronic Measurement side? And also on Varian - yes, I mean, that’s the reason why the operating margins have been impacted. But how much time do you think it’s going to take? And can that entire Varian portfolio get to the same operating margins that Chemical Analysis, for example, had in the July quarter of ’08 when you had about 28%?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are absolutely committed to drive efficiency in the Varian portfolio. The teams are in place. We are working today. We have decisions in terms of where we can consolidate operations. We have teams from the Agilent side working on what we can do to driv
componenttext: We are absolutely committed to drive efficiency in the Varian portfolio. The teams are in place. We are working today. We have decisions in terms of where we can consolidate operations. We have teams from the Agilent side working on what we can do to drive sharing of procurement purchasing across the company. And so that’s why we’re so confident over the next two to three years we will be able to get those margins out. In terms of the Electronic Measurement side, we are absolutely committed. Ron is absolutely committed to drive to the high end of our 30% to 40% incremental. So if you go back to - if Ron can continue in EMG, continue to drive the top-line growth at high-30s, 40% incremental, you’re going to drive the operating margin quite a bit higher.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just moving to the business portfolio, the second half of the ’90s, one of the big drivers of Agilent’s business was optical. And since then I think you folks have cut back quite a bit in terms of cost over there, pruned the portfolio a
componenttext: Okay. And then just moving to the business portfolio, the second half of the ’90s, one of the big drivers of Agilent’s business was optical. And since then I think you folks have cut back quite a bit in terms of cost over there, pruned the portfolio and also divested some businesses in the semiconductor product group side et cetera that had exposure there. Today, how much exposure do you have to wireline communications as a percentage of the EMG group?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our wireline percentage of the business is relatively small. Investment is still going in to optical transmission. As you know, with the IP networks, the difference between wireless and wireline is becoming blurred. I think we have a very strong pos
componenttext: Well, our wireline percentage of the business is relatively small. Investment is still going in to optical transmission. As you know, with the IP networks, the difference between wireless and wireline is becoming blurred. I think we have a very strong position moving forward, but we believe that there is going to be a recurrence of an optical boom. There is just no evidence of that moving forward. The good news is it’s not getting any worse. Our growth, actually Ron can quote where we are on our optics side, was doing okay. But we are not forecasting any resurgence of an optical boom.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Optical was approximately 38% this last quarter. But again, as Bill said, it’s a relatively small portion of the business. So we are somewhat immune to spike also on the optical side.
componenttext: Optical was approximately 38% this last quarter. But again, as Bill said, it’s a relatively small portion of the business. So we are somewhat immune to spike also on the optical side.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last question would be just - I think someone has asked something similar earlier in the call. But looking at the future acquisitions, I think, Bill, you mentioned that you don’t see yourself doing anything - Agilent doing anything si
componenttext: Okay. And then the last question would be just - I think someone has asked something similar earlier in the call. But looking at the future acquisitions, I think, Bill, you mentioned that you don’t see yourself doing anything - Agilent doing anything significant for the next six months. But in terms of priorities, which sort of broad - are the broad areas where you think that you would be more active and are looking at either consolidating transactions or enhancing the portfolio? And also, how are we looking at acquisitions now? What are the metrics you’re looking for?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’ve been very public about this. Our number one priority is to continue to expand our Life Science portfolio. We will continue to invest in the applied chemical markets, particularly on the consumables side. And we believe those are the largest market
componenttext: We’ve been very public about this. Our number one priority is to continue to expand our Life Science portfolio. We will continue to invest in the applied chemical markets, particularly on the consumables side. And we believe those are the largest markets and largest opportunity. And particularly given our strong market position already in Electronic Measurement, our criteria for acquisition remains the same. We are absolutely committed to drive value for our shareholders. The acquisitions have to be creative in year one and of course have to be able to drive something that’s above our return on capital and get back to our long-term operating model of 20% over time. So we have not changed our criteria. And we will continue to look for opportunities to expand our analytical product offerings in consumables.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is it something that is relatively small that could be on the cards or is it focused on mid-to-large size acquisitions? You mentioned that there is nothing large for the next six months, but is there a pipeline for smaller set of bolt-ons?
componenttext: And is it something that is relatively small that could be on the cards or is it focused on mid-to-large size acquisitions? You mentioned that there is nothing large for the next six months, but is there a pipeline for smaller set of bolt-ons?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, we’ve made 21 smaller acquisitions over the last five years. And so we will continue to make those types of acquisitions. They tend to be technology based, get quickly integrated into our businesses moving forward. So yes, we will continue
componenttext: As you know, we’ve made 21 smaller acquisitions over the last five years. And so we will continue to make those types of acquisitions. They tend to be technology based, get quickly integrated into our businesses moving forward. So yes, we will continue to do those, but they are not going to be material short-term to the company.

componenttext: Okay. And then so the outlook for fiscal year ’11 in EMG, can you speak to some of the secular drivers within the segments that you play outside of LTE, beyond just the Agilent strengths such as the strong product portfolio and market share gains that you are seeing? Thanks.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that overall we believe aerospace and defense business will continue to grow next year. Our business outside the US continues to be robust. The efforts that we have made in operational surveillance continue to do very, very well. And as we ma
componenttext: Yes. I think that overall we believe aerospace and defense business will continue to grow next year. Our business outside the US continues to be robust. The efforts that we have made in operational surveillance continue to do very, very well. And as we made recent public statements, we’ve done very good job of winning very large tender offers in the US military. So - and if you look at the DOD budget, there is no evidence of any severe cutback in 2011. Yes, we focus the priorities, but the fundamental investment we believe will not be a material change. Communication, as we talked about, it’s all about the growth in the wireless and the continued investment in LTE. And the industrial and computers, all going to be driven by the macroeconomic environment. Yes, we have a great product portfolio in there, but the major drive is continued investment in capital investment. So the only areas we had noted is that in the semiconductor business, will there be an isotope as the capacity catches up with demand moving forward. But as I said to a previous question, roughly about $100 million that’s kind of caught in what would be your typical semiconductor cap business. So again, not supermaterial to the outcome of the company.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Something we haven’t spoken about on this call, I think, or at least haven’t heard it, is stimulus spending and how that’s impacted your business so far and whether there is much left to benefit the company. Bill, can you give us some idea a
componenttext: Thanks. Something we haven’t spoken about on this call, I think, or at least haven’t heard it, is stimulus spending and how that’s impacted your business so far and whether there is much left to benefit the company. Bill, can you give us some idea as to how that’s helped or not helped the company?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I will give a broad editorial comment, which I have said quite publicly, and then I will have Nick have a comment. That’s where a lot of the big NIH funding is going. Governments around the world have basically invested over $2 trillion in stimulus
componenttext: Yes. I will give a broad editorial comment, which I have said quite publicly, and then I will have Nick have a comment. That’s where a lot of the big NIH funding is going. Governments around the world have basically invested over $2 trillion in stimulus money in various ways. It is my firm belief that regardless of one’s political persuasion, that $2 trillion will in fact an impact. You see the stimulus money that went into China. They still have the capability to do it again. I have Nick comment on the stimulus money in the US. Every country does it a little bit differently. And so it really is hard to track. But that investment is not only stopping the financial crisis in 2009, but in fact putting more money to academic research and across the board has had, I think, a positive impact. Very, very hard to quantify that outside of big areas like NIH.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Nick. We still see this money out there flowing. It’s just flowing slowly, and it’s coming out because of the way they put it in the system. This is not just a US comment, but certainly in the US now the money is starting to flow. It’s reall
componenttext: This is Nick. We still see this money out there flowing. It’s just flowing slowly, and it’s coming out because of the way they put it in the system. This is not just a US comment, but certainly in the US now the money is starting to flow. It’s really not going to have a huge impact for Agilent. And we think actually it’s going to have a smoothing impact on a couple year basis around the globe. You’ve seen us made some comments about some moneys coming out of Malaysia. We’re seeing money in Southeast Asia. And these moneys will continue to flow, as governments invest in healthcare and in life science researching. So we hope to catch our share, but we don’t think you’re going to see any big bumps nor big stops.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I tend to look at - adding up all the stimulus money, you can calculate - is it 1% of growth in the world or something like that, but it’s more of - the money gets spread quickly, really hard to track down.
componenttext: I tend to look at - adding up all the stimulus money, you can calculate - is it 1% of growth in the world or something like that, but it’s more of - the money gets spread quickly, really hard to track down.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Agilent Technologies Earnings Conference Call. My name is Crystal, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Ali
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Agilent Technologies Earnings Conference Call. My name is Crystal, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Alicia Rodriguez, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Crystal. Welcome, everyone, to Agilent's third quarter conference call for fiscal year 2010. With me are Agilent's President and CEO, Bill Sullivan; as well as Senior Vice President and CFO, Didier Hirsch. Joining in our Q&A will be the Preside
componenttext:
Thank you, Crystal. Welcome, everyone, to Agilent's third quarter conference call for fiscal year 2010. With me are Agilent's President and CEO, Bill Sullivan; as well as Senior Vice President and CFO, Didier Hirsch. Joining in our Q&A will be the Presidents of Agilent's Electronic Measurement, Life Sciences and Chemical Analysis Groups: Ron Nersesian, Nick Roelofs and Mike McMullen. 
After my comments, Bill will give his perspective on the quarter and the overall market environment. Didier will then follow with a review of financial results. And after Didier's comments, we will open the lines and take your questions. 
In case you haven't had a chance to review our press release, you can find it on our website at www.investor.agilent.com. Please note that we have moved the Business segment financial tables to the schedules accompanying the press release. We're also providing further information to supplement today's discussion. After you log on to our webcast module from our website, please click on the link for supporting materials. There, you will find additional information, such as our revenue break outs and historical financial information for Agilent's continuing operations.
We have also updated our investor presentation slides with scenarios that encompass the current range of first call analyst estimates for fiscal year 2011. Also in accordance with SEC Regulation G, if during this conference call we use any non-GAAP financial measures, you will find on our website the required reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial metrics. 
Additionally, I'd like to remind you that we will make forward-looking statements about the future financial performance of the company. These involve risks and uncertainties that could cause Agilent's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. 
As a result, we encourage you to look at the company's most recent filings with the SEC to get a more complete picture of all the factors at work. The forward-looking statements, including our guidance provided today during the call, are only valid as of this date, and the company assumes no obligation to update such statements as we move throughout the quarter. Now let me turn the call over to Bill for his comments.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alicia, and hello, everyone. Agilent's latest results are a strong indicator of our continued momentum. Q3 orders of $1.5 billion were up 39% year-over-year, while revenues of $1.4 billion were up 32% from a year ago. Note that these numbers inclu
componenttext:
Thanks, Alicia, and hello, everyone. Agilent's latest results are a strong indicator of our continued momentum. Q3 orders of $1.5 billion were up 39% year-over-year, while revenues of $1.4 billion were up 32% from a year ago. Note that these numbers include the results of the Varian acquisition. Without the Varian acquisition, our divestitures, orders and revenue were up 30% and 24%, respectively. 
In addition to the top line growth, we continue to improve gross margins, and our expenses were well controlled. Q3 non-GAAP earnings were $191 million or $0.54 per share. Agilent's third quarter revenue growth was strong across all regions. Excluding acquisitions and divestitures, the Americas were up 25% year-over-year, Europe 18% and Asia Pacific, up 28%. 
The Varian integration continues to go very well. We have successfully integrated Varian's field service and support functions into the existing Agilent structure. We have established three new product divisions dedicated to spectroscopy, Research Products and vacuum technologies, and we have consolidated Varian's consumables with our own Consumable business. Varian's businesses were solidly profitable in Q3. 
Moving forward, we are highly confident we will achieve our goal of a $75 million in net savings. This is inclusive of $10 million of additional R&D that we're investing in Varian's technologies as well as our increased investments in service and support. From a market perspective, our third quarter results saw a continued strength in most of our key markets that we serve. 
In our Chemical Analysis business, the applied market recovery continues. Q3 revenues of $329 million were up 62% over last year, up 13% excluding Varian. Operating margin was 21%. Excluding the Varian acquisition, we saw a double-digit, year-over-year growth in petrochemical, environmental and forensic markets. 
From a product perspective, all product lines posted double-digit order growth over a year ago. Our high-end Mass Spec business was especially strong with ICP-MS [inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry], GC/MS [Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry] and Agilent's new GC-QQQ, driving growth in food and environmental applications. And our new vacuum products are performing well in response to the improving global economy. We expect future growth to be driven by continued focus on food safety, expanding consumables and Mass Spec portfolios and the continued successful integration of Varian. 
In our Life Science businesses, revenues of $374 million were up 28% over last year. Adjusting for Varian in the high core divestiture, Life Science revenues were up 15%. Operating margin was 15%. Strength from emerging markets was offset by softness in big Pharma consolidation. 
Excluding divestitures in the Varian acquisition, academic and government revenues grew 21% over last year. We saw a more modest 6% increase in Pharma/Biotech, CRO [contract research organization] and CMO [contract manufacturing organization]. Sales of LSG [Life Sciences Group] products and services into applied markets were up 20% from a year ago. 
From a product perspective, sales of Life Science platforms into food, environmental and other applied markets remain very strong, particularly for the L/C [Liquid Chromatography] and LC/MS [Liquid Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry] instruments. L/C sales were up 25% year-over-year. The 1290 L/C continues to exceed expectations, and we introduced the new 1220 and mid-range 1260 L/Cs. Our sure-select sample prep product offerings also continue to beat expectations. 
Electronic Measurement. Revenues of $692 million were up 24% from a year ago. Excluding the network solutions divestitures, revenues grew 34%. Operating margin of 18% is at the highest level since the early 2000s. We saw strength across all markets and regions. Asia Pacific revenue is up 32%, Europe was up 18% and the Americas were up 18% year-over-year. 
In industrial markets, we saw a broad and consistent growth across multiple industries, driven by the economic recovery and growth in China. Aerospace and defense improved with spending in the United States and Asia fueling its 24% growth year-over-year. Communications demand improved with increased spending for new technologies, including LTE [Long Term Evolution] and smartphones and for 3G expansion in Asia. 
From a market perspective, our network analyzers and oscilloscopes, especially high-end scopes, were strong in all markets. Network analyzer revenue grew 58% from year ago, while scopes were up 45%. 
Moving forward, while the economy remains uncertain, we continue to see numerous market opportunities, and we believe Agilent is in a strong position to capitalize on them. There are four major areas where we differentiate ourselves. 
The first is our market reach and customer trust. We are #1 in customer loyalty in every major product category in our industry as measured by external benchmarks. With our field team now consisting of more than 6,000 sales and marketing people, we will continue to invest in customer service and support. 
Second is our technology leadership. We currently have the leading technology in every one of our core platforms: oscilloscopes, signal and spectrum analyzers, network analyzers, gas and liquid chromatography and Mass Spec. We are committed to drive to the #1 position in spectroscopy and NMR [nuclear magnetic resonance]. And as we've noted, we are increasing our R&D investment in these areas. We also continue to invest in Life Science workflow solutions and adjacent market opportunities, including nanotechnology and surveillance. 
Third is our scale and scope. Agilent's ability to scale and leverage its manufacturing capability has resulted in the leadership position in the industry. We have 6,100 manufacturing employees in every major continent with a proven track record of delivering new products to the market and dramatically driving down manufacturing cost. As a result, Agilent today has the lowest instrument cost of sales in the industry, while maintaining a reputation of high quality and reliability. 
Fourth is our team. We have completed our transformation, and we have managed successfully through the recession. Agilent's leaders and employees are able to focus externally on our customers and our market opportunity. As a result, we are in a strong position moving into Q4 and FY '11. 
We are raising our fourth quarter and full year guidance. For the fourth quarter of 2010, we expect revenues of $1.52 billion, inclusive of Varian. Non-GAAP earnings are expected to be in the range of $0.58 to $0.59 per share. For the full fiscal year 2010, we expect revenues of $5.4 billion and a non-GAAP earnings of $1.94 to $1.95 per share. 
Thank you for being on the call. And now, I'll turn it over to Didier.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good afternoon, everyone. I will start by providing additional color on the third quarter results and the fourth quarter outlook. Then, I will give an update on the Varian integration and a perspective on potential scenarios in fiscal
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good afternoon, everyone. I will start by providing additional color on the third quarter results and the fourth quarter outlook. Then, I will give an update on the Varian integration and a perspective on potential scenarios in fiscal year '11. 
My comments on the results will focus on the year-over-year comparisons, and I will report year-over-year top line growth percentages, both with and without the high core network solution divestitures and the Varian acquisition, in other words, the organic and inorganic view of order and revenue growth.
Starting with Q3 results, as Bill stated, Agilent delivered strong third quarter results. Those results show that we're delivering on our commitment to exit the recession in a much stronger position than when the downturn began. 
During the downturn, we maintained our large investment in R&D and expanded our channel and reach. We also restructured EMG [Electronics Measurement Group]. We believe we have strengthened an operating model that is a significant competitive advantage in the short and long term. 
Orders of $1.5 billion were up 39% from one year ago, both in dollars and local currency. On an organic basis, orders grew 30%, with Asia Pacific up 51%, the Americas up 20% and Europe up 14%. 
Revenue was up $1.4 billion or up 32% in dollars and local currency from one year ago or 24% in an organic basis. Both three business segments generated double-digit revenue growth, both in total and organically. 
Domestic revenues on an organic basis were up 28% in Asia Pacific, up 25% in the Americas and grew 18% in Europe. Organic revenue growth in China and India were very solid at 24% and 43%, respectively. 
Now moving to the income statement. Third quarter non-GAAP operating profit of $251 million was $170 million above one year ago on a $338 million increase in revenue, yielding a 50% operating margin incremental. Excluding Varian, our year-over-year operating margin incremental was 83%, with all three segments delivering excellent incrementals. 
The key factors driving these outstanding year-over-year performance were volume-related gross margin incrementals and restructuring savings. These were partly offset by the impact of the restoration of full pay and higher variable and incentives. Currency had minimal impact on any of the income statement line item.
Now turning to the individual income statement line items. Third quarter gross margins of 56% were 2.8 points higher than last year. Excluding Varian, gross margins reached an all-time high and improved by 4.2 points over last year or about two points on a volume-adjusted basis. 
Third quarter operating expenses increased $49 million mostly due to the impact of the Varian acquisition. Wage restoration and higher variable and incentive pay were offset by restructuring pay. 
Operating profits of $251 million were up more than 200% from last year. The company's third quarter operating margin was 18%, an increase of 10 points from one year ago and well above our mid-cycle target of 14%. Net other income and expense declined $5 million from last year, mostly due to higher interest expenses. 
Moving to taxes, we are reducing our fiscal year 2010 non-GAAP tax rate from 20% to 19%, which results in a 17.5% tax rate for Q3 and one additional cent per share. Non-GAAP net income of $191 million or $0.54 per share compares to $53 million or $0.15 per share one year ago.
Turning to the cash flow and the balance sheet, we continue to show outstanding discipline in asset management. Inventory days on hand of 97 days were nine days better than one year ago on $117 million in higher inventories and increased largely due to the Varian acquisition. Receivables days sales outstanding increased four days from one year ago to 50, again primarily due to the Varian acquisition. Total cash from operations was $90 million, an increase of $49 million from one year ago. 
During the quarter, we raised $40 million from employee stock programs and repurchased $94 million worth of shares. Year-to-date, we've raised $264 million and repurchased $359 million. As you know, we intend to maintain our basic outstanding share count at about 346 million shares, while the diluted share count will remain north of 350 million shares depending on the stock volume. With regard to net cash, we finished the quarter with net cash of $267 million. 
Now let me say a word on the $1.5 billion World Trade debt maturing in January. As you know, we had a very successful debt offering on July 13 and raised $750 million. We intend to pay off the World Trade debt in its entirety when it matures in January 2011, using the proceeds of the debt offering and cash from our balance sheet. We will incur an additional $5 million in interest expense in Q4 2010 and Q1 2011. But starting in Q2 2011, we will save $7 million per quarter after we delever.
Now onto the Varian integration. As Bill stated, we are making excellent progress in integrating Varian and capitalizing on the revenue and cost synergies that we expected. With our expanded portfolio and capabilities, we have started capturing market opportunities. 
We also remain committed to the $75 million in first synergies that we previously communicated even net of incremental investments in R&D, service and support. On November 1, we will combine all the Varian and Agilent legal entities. In short, we are pleased to confirm that our integration, revenue and cost synergy plans are on track. 
Now turning to the fiscal year '10 outlook, we expect Agilent Q4 revenues to be about $1.52 billion, 30% above last year or a 21% growth on an organic basis. Q4 revenues of $1.52 billion would represent an approximate increase of $120 million over Q3 revenue. 
On an earnings-per-share basis, we expect a sequential increase of $0.04 to $0.05 above Q3 level of $0.54, leading to an expected Q4 EPS of $0.58 to $0.59. Now these would represent a somewhat lower sequential in incremental than normal for the following four reasons. 
First, about $35 million of the sequential revenue increases for Varian products and services as legal incremental as the corresponding increase in gross margin is offset by increased Varian expenses, which in Q4, reflect an additional two weeks of expenses over Q3. Second, Q4 earnings per share do not have the $0.01 benefit of the tax true-up that we saw in Q3. Third, Q4 earnings per share reflect the negative carry of the new $750 million debt worth about $0.01. And fourth, Q4 earnings per share include end-of-semester variable and incentive pay increases of about $0.02 on the back of the semester's projected outstanding result. You will also note that we have added the 3,100 plus ex-Varian employees to the program. 
On a full-year basis, we now expect revenues of roughly $5.4 billion in fiscal year '10, an increase of 20% over last year or 18% growth on an organic basis, an EPS of $1.94 to $1.95. The new EPS guidance represent an increase of $0.14 over the midpoint of the previous guidance of $1.78 to $1.83 and reflects our commitment to strong incrementals as we continue to deliver on our operating model.
Now moving to fiscal year '11 scenarios, we're currently finalizing our three-year strategic plans for review with the board as we do every year in September. As part of this exercise, we model various economic scenarios and identify triggers and actions that we'll need to take under different conditions as we have proactively done in the past. 
As Alicia mentioned, an investor presentation is posted on our website. It includes two scenarios that encompass the current branch of fiscal call analyst estimates for fiscal year 2011. Under one scenario, our fiscal year '11 revenues of $6.2 billion, a 15% year-over-year increase or 9% organic growth, which in turn would drive an EPS of $2.50. 
Under the second scenario, fiscal year '11 revenues would reach $5.9 billion. This is a 10% year-over-year increase or 4% growth on an organic basis, which yields an EPS of $2.15. As Bill stated, we'll provide guidance for fiscal year '11 in November. With that, I'll turn it over to Alicia for the Q&A.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010

componenttext: So Bill, understanding kind of the parameters you laid out for FY '11 here, can you just at least qualitatively walk us through the puts and takes on how you're looking at Electronic Measurement next year? Obviously, we're still way below the peak of '08 in the current year. But cognizant of the headlines we see, can you just kind of talk through some of the positives and negatives on the horizon you see for that business next year?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So first of all, as you can see by our incoming order rate, there's no evidence of the slowdown anywhere in the world or any of our product lines. And that right now, there's just no evidence of a slowdown. In terms of EMG, and again, Ron can add any addi
componenttext: So first of all, as you can see by our incoming order rate, there's no evidence of the slowdown anywhere in the world or any of our product lines. And that right now, there's just no evidence of a slowdown. In terms of EMG, and again, Ron can add any additional color commentary, the biggest downside potential is for the semiconductor industry, which is a small part of our business but real, could in fact ask them to help out going in next year. Offsetting that, we continue to see the investment in LTE. We continue to do exceedingly well in LTE R&D. We continue to do well with the expansion in smartphones. We continue to do very, very well in aerospace and defense, and we do very well across a very broad industrial base. EMG is a much different organization than it was before the last downturn. And so, outside of a pause in semiconductor investment, which is a very small part of our business, everything as it stands today, looks quite positive. Ron, any additional comments?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you hit it right on the head, Bill. The only other thing I would add is that our core products are up dramatically. If you look at our oscilloscopes, network analyzers, signal analyzers and signal sources, they were up 50% in revenue compared to t
componenttext: I think you hit it right on the head, Bill. The only other thing I would add is that our core products are up dramatically. If you look at our oscilloscopes, network analyzers, signal analyzers and signal sources, they were up 50% in revenue compared to the same quarter a year ago. Now also, what we are seeing is more of a shift of our business from wireless manufacturing to wireless R&D. And that is a more stable business, and that really aligns with the LTE cycle that we're beginning to see. For instance, in China, our Wireless R&D business was up 85% this quarter. So overall, I think that gives some color commentary to what's going on in EMG.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as I noted in my comments, given the investment, and Didier also mentioned this, we invested substantially during the downturn, and we are in the strongest position in our history and our products. And technically, we have the highest performing instr
componenttext: And as I noted in my comments, given the investment, and Didier also mentioned this, we invested substantially during the downturn, and we are in the strongest position in our history and our products. And technically, we have the highest performing instrument in every product category in the industry.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one last on capital deployment. You mentioned, still the #1 priority for cash is I guess in inorganic as well as organic investment. What do you see, Bill, in terms of the acquisition landscape at this point? I mean, should we anticipate you to be act
componenttext: And one last on capital deployment. You mentioned, still the #1 priority for cash is I guess in inorganic as well as organic investment. What do you see, Bill, in terms of the acquisition landscape at this point? I mean, should we anticipate you to be active over the next six months or so on the acquisition side?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not over the next six months. We must integrate Varian successfully. Again, I'm very, very pleased with the progress to date. But I'd be very unrealistic for us to take on a major acquisition over the next six months. Didier said we will pay down the
componenttext: No, not over the next six months. We must integrate Varian successfully. Again, I'm very, very pleased with the progress to date. But I'd be very unrealistic for us to take on a major acquisition over the next six months. Didier said we will pay down the World Trade debt. We will continue to generate cash. And as you said, our #1 priority, six months at the end of next year, is to see what is the right inorganic investment we can make to continue to drive value for our shareholders. And then, of course, given our history, we'll return remaining cash to the shareholder.
