headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just a kind of a follow up on that one of the last questions around the EMG revenue. At some quarters back in fiscal '08, you're over $900 million in revenue quarter. Do you see that as kind of achievable over the next cycle? Or has anything change
componenttext: First, just a kind of a follow up on that one of the last questions around the EMG revenue. At some quarters back in fiscal '08, you're over $900 million in revenue quarter. Do you see that as kind of achievable over the next cycle? Or has anything changed fundamentally in the business or in your position that might make that more difficult?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we -- and I'll have Ron make a comment. We divested our Network business. And so, we have a part of the market that we no longer participate in. So you would have to discount the high point of our Networking business. But if we are successfu
componenttext: Well, I mean, we -- and I'll have Ron make a comment. We divested our Network business. And so, we have a part of the market that we no longer participate in. So you would have to discount the high point of our Networking business. But if we are successful in our product strategy, successful in each of these segments there is no reason why we could not move back to our historic position in all of these product lines.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that it's exactly correct. The only addition I would make is that we're shifting away from going after some business in manufacturing that has very low gross margins and low probability in placing more of our portfolio in R&D. So that is why
componenttext: Yes. I think that it's exactly correct. The only addition I would make is that we're shifting away from going after some business in manufacturing that has very low gross margins and low probability in placing more of our portfolio in R&D. So that is why you're seeing very, very high gross margins of 59% for EMG and 18% operating profit even at this level of revenue, slightly below $700 million. So it's not just the revenue line, but our earnings potential is much greater as we shift of the mix of our portfolio.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because it seems clear that you believed we're not at/or very close to peak in that business, can you give us an update on the distribution strategy? I understand that as part of the restructuring in EMG, you adopted a bit more of an indirect selling stra
componenttext: Because it seems clear that you believed we're not at/or very close to peak in that business, can you give us an update on the distribution strategy? I understand that as part of the restructuring in EMG, you adopted a bit more of an indirect selling strategy. Can you update us on that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Overall, our primary channel to go to the market is our direct sales strategy. But clearly, with our direct sales, we cannot go ahead and get all of the reach that we want, so we're working very effectively with many partners. And accordingly, in th
componenttext: Sure. Overall, our primary channel to go to the market is our direct sales strategy. But clearly, with our direct sales, we cannot go ahead and get all of the reach that we want, so we're working very effectively with many partners. And accordingly, in the last year, we've taken the percentage of our sales and distribution from roughly 9% to about 18%. So it's twice as much of our business on a percentage basis is going through distribution. If you look at it on a dollar basis, our indirect sales were up 89% this last quarter. And that's why you see great growth in product lines such as oscilloscopes. So oscilloscope order growth -- we stated the revenue growth of 45%, but our oscilloscope order growth was over 50%. And that's because of the great high-performance products that were introduced in April, but also because of the lower-end scopes that are sold through distribution. So the distribution strategy is working exceptionally well. We've doubled the percentage of business of our business that goes through distribution, and we plan to continue to go much, much further with that as we continue to execute our strategy.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Annie impact from supply-chain issues like component shortages, which we've heard so much about from other companies this quarter?
componenttext: Annie impact from supply-chain issues like component shortages, which we've heard so much about from other companies this quarter?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have had part shortages across everyone of our product lines. Again, this is issue in the industry. Actually, some of the Varian product lines have been impacted even more than some of our product lines in Life Science, for example, or in Ron's busines
componenttext: We have had part shortages across everyone of our product lines. Again, this is issue in the industry. Actually, some of the Varian product lines have been impacted even more than some of our product lines in Life Science, for example, or in Ron's business, in EMG. The team continues to do a great job of trying to expedite parts moving forward, but it has had a negative impact on our ability to turn these very robust orders into revenue. We will continue to catch up as we move forward in Q4, but we have not been immune to the part shortages.

componenttext: Can you maybe talk any more specifically I guess around Varian and your first priority was to stabilize the orders there? So maybe just talk about kind of how that's gone since the acquisition is closed?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. And again, both Mike and Nick make a comment. But the team has done, I think, just an extraordinary job of integrating the Varian sales team into ours. Very, very quickly, we have put programs in place. We have put too, in fact, to drive order lead
componenttext: Right. And again, both Mike and Nick make a comment. But the team has done, I think, just an extraordinary job of integrating the Varian sales team into ours. Very, very quickly, we have put programs in place. We have put too, in fact, to drive order lead generation. We have put together an extensive training program to ensure that Agilent employees or sales people can sell Varian products. And so, again, we're early into this. But from my perspective, we have made enormous progress, which is, typically, the most difficult part of the process is to integrate the sales organization. Mike, Nick, any additional comments?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill, if I could just build on your comments. We're really focusing, Jonathan, on driving that leverage from the combined sales force. As Bill mentioned, we have some programs that put in place that already are delivering significant amounts of incre
componenttext: Yes, Bill, if I could just build on your comments. We're really focusing, Jonathan, on driving that leverage from the combined sales force. As Bill mentioned, we have some programs that put in place that already are delivering significant amounts of incremental leads and actually closing some new business. So really pleased with how the customers respond to the combined portfolio. And this combined sales force effort really is yielding us results we hoped to when we first went down this path.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Nick. I'll skew off Mike's comment. 80 days in, we've turned that focus, as Mike just pointed to. We've got the internal stuff pretty well along. We're working with the external stuff, and now we're fixing customer communications and fixing servic
componenttext: This is Nick. I'll skew off Mike's comment. 80 days in, we've turned that focus, as Mike just pointed to. We've got the internal stuff pretty well along. We're working with the external stuff, and now we're fixing customer communications and fixing service. And we're really here to stay. We're here to put the investment, and customer's starting to see it.

componenttext: You had said, I think Varian would add about $370 million in revenues once it's closed for the year. I was just curious if there was change in that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, I mean, the total number because of the old Agilent products we're in very, very strong position because of the part shortages, I think that the revenue number will come in roughly $20 million shorter on the Varian side than we anticipated. No
componenttext: Right now, I mean, the total number because of the old Agilent products we're in very, very strong position because of the part shortages, I think that the revenue number will come in roughly $20 million shorter on the Varian side than we anticipated. No material impact in total, but that is happening just because of part shortages. And I think there's about another $10 million of revenue that's being absorbed into the Agilent product lines, as we notify customers of how we are going to merge some of the overlapping product lines that were not divested. And so I think that there'll be some smaller impact. But again, as we regain the order momentum to the programs that Mike and Nick talked about, I think that we're going to easily offset the $20 million moving forward into FY '11. Secondly, we aggressively are putting in people and teams to try to expedite the parts coming in so that we can catch up on our backlog.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, you said that the business remains very robust. Just curious if you can, if there's any detail to add, I guess, you talked a lot about Electronic Measurement, but maybe more on Life Sciences, Chemical Analysis side, in terms of what you saw spe
componenttext: Obviously, you said that the business remains very robust. Just curious if you can, if there's any detail to add, I guess, you talked a lot about Electronic Measurement, but maybe more on Life Sciences, Chemical Analysis side, in terms of what you saw specifically maybe in July towards the end of the last quarter. And some other Life Sciences companies were saying they're starting to see some things slow in Europe in particular and maybe a little bit in the U.S. I'm just I guess curious what you guys saw as you exited your quarter?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you can see by our numbers, our organic growth rate in both Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences is very robust. But I'll have Mike and Nick give their color commentary in terms of any trends. But again, we had a strong quarter.
componenttext: As you can see by our numbers, our organic growth rate in both Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences is very robust. But I'll have Mike and Nick give their color commentary in terms of any trends. But again, we had a strong quarter.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Nick. Just a quick comment. So we had double-digit growth across all regions in Life Science, with Europe doing about 13%. So we haven't seen any softness in Europe, and we built backlog for range of reasons, including the part issues sort of unin
componenttext: This is Nick. Just a quick comment. So we had double-digit growth across all regions in Life Science, with Europe doing about 13%. So we haven't seen any softness in Europe, and we built backlog for range of reasons, including the part issues sort of unintentional. So we're in a pretty strong position. We're not seeing slowdowns. And if anything, we keep commenting about Pharma, it's moved into positive growth territory, including Europe. So while it's soft and it's coming back slow, we're seeing real growth come back across the board. So whatever weakness is out there, it may be in sectors that we don't touch as strongly like the academic in Europe where we're not as big a player.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, similar message on the Chemical Analysis. We have continued strong recovery in both the America and Europe and the continuation of the Asia growth story for us.
componenttext: Jonathan, similar message on the Chemical Analysis. We have continued strong recovery in both the America and Europe and the continuation of the Asia growth story for us.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Butler with Barclays Capital.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, again, to Varian, something new to Agilent, and it's obviously more -- is that where you're having part shortages? And moreover, are you having increasing demand there now that you're able to consolidate sales force and actually push that?
componenttext: One, again, to Varian, something new to Agilent, and it's obviously more -- is that where you're having part shortages? And moreover, are you having increasing demand there now that you're able to consolidate sales force and actually push that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The part shortages across the board. Number one part shortages is Electronic Measurement, it's got the highest growth; secondly, I would say, Varian; third one would be in the Life Science area. But I'm going to have both Mike and then Nick comment about
componenttext: The part shortages across the board. Number one part shortages is Electronic Measurement, it's got the highest growth; secondly, I would say, Varian; third one would be in the Life Science area. But I'm going to have both Mike and then Nick comment about the product portfolios. As I said in my comment, we are committed to -- we're not sure that when this will happen, but we will drive to become number one in spectroscopy, as well as in NMR, and we're taking actions to do that. But Mike, why don't you make a few comments, and then Nick about what you're seeing what the product portfolio that has come into the company?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about the three product categories. First of all, Bill mentioned the drive in spectroscopy, our drive to be number one. We're seeing already leverage from the combined sales force generating increased demand, and we plan a stepped up R&D inves
componenttext: Let me talk about the three product categories. First of all, Bill mentioned the drive in spectroscopy, our drive to be number one. We're seeing already leverage from the combined sales force generating increased demand, and we plan a stepped up R&D investments and continue to enhance our portfolio. So good news there. We have not talked about this in this call today, but the consumers also are very price thought for us. We now have three additional divisions that been consolidated into our Consumables business. And already the new Agilent sales-force is selling the sample prep products from the Varian portfolio, so we're getting good solid growth there. And then the Vacuum business, which we've not talked a lot about today as well, up 34% over last year and a nice recovery mode as well.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add, research products is pretty broad portfolio. NMR is the big business in there. It's too early, these are long-cycle developments and long-cycle orders. So our commitment to R&D in that sector is really resonating with customers. We are
componenttext: And I'll just add, research products is pretty broad portfolio. NMR is the big business in there. It's too early, these are long-cycle developments and long-cycle orders. So our commitment to R&D in that sector is really resonating with customers. We are seeing some real funnel growth and some actual order growth. But at this point, the order cycle is so long that I can't claim any victories there.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the last question is around LC, I know it was up 25% I think. Comments made around not only 1290 but the midrange LC products. Is this the result of commitments for new orders or is it replacement orders?
componenttext: And the last question is around LC, I know it was up 25% I think. Comments made around not only 1290 but the midrange LC products. Is this the result of commitments for new orders or is it replacement orders?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really the whole spectrum, Tony. We're seeing everything across the board, but it's just a really strong product in the 1290. We followed up with new members to our family at the midrange and low-end. So now we've got the most modern portfolio
componenttext: Well, it's really the whole spectrum, Tony. We're seeing everything across the board, but it's just a really strong product in the 1290. We followed up with new members to our family at the midrange and low-end. So now we've got the most modern portfolio across the entire range. And as you can see, we're doing very well, but we're getting a lot of growth out of the applied markets as well, and those markets are places where there's new market creation. So we're really proud of that 25% growth.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, could you just talk for a second, within the EMG Group or business, Europe was up 18%. And could you just kind of explain maybe that number a little bit. And are we seeing may be a fundamental upshift in R&D spend? Or are we really seeing a bounce f
componenttext: Bill, could you just talk for a second, within the EMG Group or business, Europe was up 18%. And could you just kind of explain maybe that number a little bit. And are we seeing may be a fundamental upshift in R&D spend? Or are we really seeing a bounce from last year, because 18% out of Europe these days is a pretty impressive number?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, this quarter, I'm going to spend a lot of time bragging about the great product portfolio that we have. And I can't stress enough the transformation the company has gone through moving forward. But I'm going to have Ron comment about Europe specifi
componenttext: Again, this quarter, I'm going to spend a lot of time bragging about the great product portfolio that we have. And I can't stress enough the transformation the company has gone through moving forward. But I'm going to have Ron comment about Europe specifically. Again, given how strong our growth was. Go ahead, Ron.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Although Americas and Europe both had 18% revenue growth, Europe actually outgrew the Americas with 24% order growth. So we're seeing very solid results in Europe. And as Bill had mentioned earlier, we haven't seen any signs of a downturn at all. As
componenttext: Sure. Although Americas and Europe both had 18% revenue growth, Europe actually outgrew the Americas with 24% order growth. So we're seeing very solid results in Europe. And as Bill had mentioned earlier, we haven't seen any signs of a downturn at all. As a matter of fact, orders are very, very robust across the board. So the business that is there, there is some manufacturing in Europe but there's obviously a lot of wireless R&D that we play in, and we play across the overall wireless food chain, as well as in the general electronics and communications space. So the short answer is, we haven't seen a slowdown. The growth in Europe actually even outpaced the Americas.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there any leadership there in Europe on the LTE side? Have they maybe jumped to a bit of a leadership in terms of not only development, but deployment? Or is that not a big factor in that growth rate?
componenttext: Is there any leadership there in Europe on the LTE side? Have they maybe jumped to a bit of a leadership in terms of not only development, but deployment? Or is that not a big factor in that growth rate?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's not a big factor in the growth rate. Now you have more R&D for wireless handsets and reference design houses in Europe, but there's even more of a shift to that over to Asia. So if you're looking for a shift in the balance of the players by regions
componenttext: That's not a big factor in the growth rate. Now you have more R&D for wireless handsets and reference design houses in Europe, but there's even more of a shift to that over to Asia. So if you're looking for a shift in the balance of the players by regions, China is actually starting to grow more and more, and they're implementing their version of LTE, called TD-LTE, which will probably be adopted in India as well. But it's pretty much across-the-board. Our oscilloscope products are also very strong; our network analyzer products, as Bill mentioned. And we're seeing good strong order growth from all of our product lines at this time.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one follow-up, maybe for Didier. When you talked about some preliminary thoughts about fiscal '11 in that forecast, obviously, the difference between scenario one and two was just that core growth or organic growth assumption. And I'm curiou
componenttext: And then just one follow-up, maybe for Didier. When you talked about some preliminary thoughts about fiscal '11 in that forecast, obviously, the difference between scenario one and two was just that core growth or organic growth assumption. And I'm curious, given let's just say the three parts of the business between CA, LS and EMG, is the difference in that core growth rate, is it primarily the assumption that you're using an EMG? In other words, is L-C, or CA and LS, are they pretty much static growth in both of those scenarios?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: They are more comparable in EM. In both scenarios, we're assuming lower growth than within that market.
componenttext: They are more comparable in EM. In both scenarios, we're assuming lower growth than within that market.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the first scenario, we're assuming approximately 7% growth for EMG, which corresponds to the SIA Index and where it's expected to be for next year at 6.3%, with minor share gains. And again, that's a relatively conservative number compared to this
componenttext: Yes. In the first scenario, we're assuming approximately 7% growth for EMG, which corresponds to the SIA Index and where it's expected to be for next year at 6.3%, with minor share gains. And again, that's a relatively conservative number compared to this year. In the second scenario, we're closer to flat. And the primary sector or subsegment of that is the Semiconductor business, where we have modest growth in the first scenario. And in the second scenario, we could withstand approximately a 45% decline in the Semiconductor segment and still deliver the second scenario.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is the annualized run rate there? I mean, are we talking about maybe $160 million in revenue? I mean, just off of the third quarter performance, just to size it.
componenttext: And is the annualized run rate there? I mean, are we talking about maybe $160 million in revenue? I mean, just off of the third quarter performance, just to size it.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ask the question again, please.
componenttext: Ask the question again, please.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at the Semiconductor revenue in the third quarter of this year just completed. If you were to annualize that number, what is the order of magnitude of the revenue right now?
componenttext: Looking at the Semiconductor revenue in the third quarter of this year just completed. If you were to annualize that number, what is the order of magnitude of the revenue right now?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not reporting that number. There's different parts of our business that actually play into the Semiconductor business, direct products such as our parametric test products and then other products that -- there's going to be -- so much of our investm
componenttext: We're not reporting that number. There's different parts of our business that actually play into the Semiconductor business, direct products such as our parametric test products and then other products that -- there's going to be -- so much of our investments in semi would go into the chip design, and again, where we have a strong position our scopes, and we pick the whole PCI Express moving forward. I think it's fair, Ron, that in terms of stuff that is tied, we still have a small business tied directly to IC-CAP, and that's probably in $100 million range that you're talking about. So it's not very large. So if you assume an organic growth rate, let's say, normally at seven, you get to nine with a stronger EMG, a little bit below that with a weaker EMG, that's how I would characterize it. And as simple as that and obviously, nail this down next month and report it in our guidance moving forward. But that's how I look at it, seven plus or minus a couple, barring a major downturn.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we go back to EMG, any adjustments right now into your expectations for mid-cycle margins? I mean, versus your latest mid-cycle target you gave early this year, I mean, you're not at good cycle yet but you're already at 18%. How should we think about
componenttext: When we go back to EMG, any adjustments right now into your expectations for mid-cycle margins? I mean, versus your latest mid-cycle target you gave early this year, I mean, you're not at good cycle yet but you're already at 18%. How should we think about that going forward?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Ron can do really well, so I'll let him answer the question.
componenttext: I think Ron can do really well, so I'll let him answer the question.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we mentioned earlier, operating margin at this point is at 18%, and we talked about a $600 million per quarter run rate or $2.4 billion bottom or trough, that we would produce 12% operating margin and 21% at the peak. We're clearly  well above the
componenttext: Yes, as we mentioned earlier, operating margin at this point is at 18%, and we talked about a $600 million per quarter run rate or $2.4 billion bottom or trough, that we would produce 12% operating margin and 21% at the peak. We're clearly  well above the midpoint right now, and our margins continue to be healthy. And our guidance will reflect what we think we can deliver in EM.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have spoken about this. The transformation of EMG has just been dramatic. And it won't take much for Ron to get over 20% operating profit depending on the recovery. You couple that with two other parts of the business that historically have been growin
componenttext: We have spoken about this. The transformation of EMG has just been dramatic. And it won't take much for Ron to get over 20% operating profit depending on the recovery. You couple that with two other parts of the business that historically have been growing substantially above the organic growth rate of the market, it's just a great combination. And again, another plug-in for EMG, this is by the first quarter that we believe that the organic growth rate was higher than the market. And so Ron's transformation is done, got a great product portfolio moving forward. And you couple that with the Varian acquisition and the continued strong position of our Chemical business and Life Science business, I think that we're very well positioned moving into 2011.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Ron, also on your lower-priced oscilloscopes, the sell-through for that, is that matching your expectations, exceeding your expectations? Do you pretty much believe you're getting some share gains there?
componenttext: And then, Ron, also on your lower-priced oscilloscopes, the sell-through for that, is that matching your expectations, exceeding your expectations? Do you pretty much believe you're getting some share gains there?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're pretty sure that we are getting share gains. And again, with over 50% order growth and when we look at the sell-through working with distributors, we feel very confident that we are taking share in that space. And again, the 45% revenue growth
componenttext: Yes, we're pretty sure that we are getting share gains. And again, with over 50% order growth and when we look at the sell-through working with distributors, we feel very confident that we are taking share in that space. And again, the 45% revenue growth was basically supply-limited or we could have delivered even more than that. But we're pretty confident that we're taking share and we're penetrating areas where Tektronix used to play, as our lower-end product line and mid-range product line is more competitive. And at the high end, we have the world's highest performance realtime bandwidth, that really is a very, very large deal for our leading-edge customers. So we're very, very pleased with our overall oscilloscope product line. And again, we've grown faster in the oscilloscope product line over the last eight years than any other player in the industry, and we're excited to see the share gain we'll continue to get.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there possibility of a modular hardware release anytime in the near term? If so when are you thinking about that?
componenttext: Is there possibility of a modular hardware release anytime in the near term? If so when are you thinking about that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't make any pre-announcements of products until they're ready to go and they're on the shelf.
componenttext: We don't make any pre-announcements of products until they're ready to go and they're on the shelf.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Knight with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Knight with CLSA.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, what was the growth in Japan in the quarter just posted?
componenttext: Bill, what was the growth in Japan in the quarter just posted?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Japanese growth was 16% year-over-year.
componenttext: The Japanese growth was 16% year-over-year.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So no real slowdown from the stimulus there?
componenttext: So no real slowdown from the stimulus there?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sequentially, it was down. So you always get a big mix at least year-over-year. And in fairness, we got -- the compares are that we'll get worse, more difficult as we move forward. But again, the Japanese business was okay.
componenttext: Sequentially, it was down. So you always get a big mix at least year-over-year. And in fairness, we got -- the compares are that we'll get worse, more difficult as we move forward. But again, the Japanese business was okay.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then if we look at the EMG business today, what portion is it roughly going into these R&D markets? Is it a quarter, a third? What's that level?
componenttext: And then if we look at the EMG business today, what portion is it roughly going into these R&D markets? Is it a quarter, a third? What's that level?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's between a third and half of our business is going into the R&D markets today, and we expect that number to migrate up. And just a follow-up on the last question, revenue tells you a little bit about what's going on in the market. So if you're looking
componenttext: It's between a third and half of our business is going into the R&D markets today, and we expect that number to migrate up. And just a follow-up on the last question, revenue tells you a little bit about what's going on in the market. So if you're looking if there's a slowdown or not, orders has evened more timely. Our orders for EMG in Japan were up 69% this last quarter.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And for the company overall, orders were up 45% on an organic basis.
componenttext: And for the company overall, orders were up 45% on an organic basis.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why do you think that is occurring?
componenttext: Why do you think that is occurring?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're seeing some investments in LTE in Japan. They plan to launch in 2010. There's a lot of spending right now on base stations, and Japan is providing a lot of component to feed into the China market. So the success in Japan is not necessarily just abou
componenttext: We're seeing some investments in LTE in Japan. They plan to launch in 2010. There's a lot of spending right now on base stations, and Japan is providing a lot of component to feed into the China market. So the success in Japan is not necessarily just about the Japanese end market, but it's really about China. And as we talked about, our China growth is very strong at over 60% for EMG.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Bill, lastly, what type of GDP in Europe would you assume under scenario two?
componenttext: And Bill, lastly, what type of GDP in Europe would you assume under scenario two?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Quite honestly, I wish that Agilent could have an impact on the world's gross domestic product overall moving forward, and that's why it's so important for us to focus our investment where the money is, where people need measurement tools. And I thin
componenttext: Yes. Quite honestly, I wish that Agilent could have an impact on the world's gross domestic product overall moving forward, and that's why it's so important for us to focus our investment where the money is, where people need measurement tools. And I think some of the numbers that we are sharing with you today is indicative of our ability to have the right products for the market needs. Again, this recovery is very, very fragmented. You really need to go into each one of these market segments to really understand what's going on. And fortunately, we don't make any measurement solutions for the construction industry as an example for that. But our overall assumption in Europe that the Gross Domestic Product will grow in the one plus percent range.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ajit Pai with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ajit Pai with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to visit your operating margin for the overall company. I think you've had a record sort of third quarter operating margin this time and materially lower revenues. In think you've attributed some of that to a mixed shift on the EMG side. But y
componenttext: Just wanted to visit your operating margin for the overall company. I think you've had a record sort of third quarter operating margin this time and materially lower revenues. In think you've attributed some of that to a mixed shift on the EMG side. But your margins right now are still below your targets in EMG for peak targets. And also, for when you look at your Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences margins, on an operating side, they are significantly lower than what you have delivered in the recent past, in '08. So from a broad perspective, where do you expect your operating margins to go over the next couple of years? How much higher and on what level of revenue?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The operating model for Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences, as you know, are being impacted with the Varian acquisition, the gross margin difference doing Varian ourselves are 10 points, and we are fully committed to make up that difference. And that's w
componenttext: The operating model for Chemical Analysis and Life Sciences, as you know, are being impacted with the Varian acquisition, the gross margin difference doing Varian ourselves are 10 points, and we are fully committed to make up that difference. And that's why we're so confident that we will be able to drive the $75 million of net savings moving forward. In terms of the margins for Electronic Measurement, I'm confused on your question because both the gross margin and the operating profit in Electronic Measurement are close to record highs.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. How much higher can they go on Electronic Measurement side? And also in Varian, yes, I mean, that's the reason why the operating margins have been impacted, but how much time do you think it's going to take? And again, that entire Varian portfolio
componenttext: Right. How much higher can they go on Electronic Measurement side? And also in Varian, yes, I mean, that's the reason why the operating margins have been impacted, but how much time do you think it's going to take? And again, that entire Varian portfolio get to the same operating margins that Chemical Analysis, for example, had in the July quarter of '08 when you had about 28%?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are absolutely committed to drive efficiency in the Varian portfolio. The teams are in place. We are working today. We have made decisions in terms of where we can consolidate operations. We have  teams from the Agilent side working on what we can do t
componenttext: We are absolutely committed to drive efficiency in the Varian portfolio. The teams are in place. We are working today. We have made decisions in terms of where we can consolidate operations. We have  teams from the Agilent side working on what we can do to drive sharing of procurement purchasing across the company. And so that's why we're so confident over the next two to three years, we will be able to get those margins out. In terms of Electronic Measurement side, we are absolutely committed. Ron is absolutely committed to drive to the high end of our 30% to 40% incremental. So if you go back to, if Ron can continue and EMG continue to drive the top line growth in the high30s, 40% increment, you're going to drive the operating margin quite a bit higher.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just moving to the business portfolio, the second half of the '90 is one of the big drivers of Agilent's business was optical. And since then, I think you folks have cut back quite a bit in terms of cost over there, through the portfolio and also dive
componenttext: And just moving to the business portfolio, the second half of the '90 is one of the big drivers of Agilent's business was optical. And since then, I think you folks have cut back quite a bit in terms of cost over there, through the portfolio and also divested some businesses on the semiconductor product group side et cetera that had exposure there. Today, how much exposure you have to wireline communication as a percentage of the EMG Group?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our wireline percentage of the business is relatively small. Investment is still going in through optical transmission. As you know, with IP networks, the difference between wireless and wireline is becoming blurred. I think we have a very strong po
componenttext: Well, our wireline percentage of the business is relatively small. Investment is still going in through optical transmission. As you know, with IP networks, the difference between wireless and wireline is becoming blurred. I think we have a very strong position moving forward but to believe that there's going to be a recurrence of an optical boom, there's just no evidence of that moving forward. Good news is, it's not getting any worse. Our growth actually Ron quote, where we are in our optics side, we're doing okay. But we're not forecasting any resurgence of an optical boom.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Optical was approximately 38% of last quarter. But again, as Bill said, it's relatively small portion of the business that we're somewhat immune to cycles in the optical side.
componenttext: Optical was approximately 38% of last quarter. But again, as Bill said, it's relatively small portion of the business that we're somewhat immune to cycles in the optical side.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: But looking at the future acquisitions, I think, Bill, you said mentioned that you don't see yourself doing anything, Agilent doing anything significant for the next six months. But in terms of priorities, which sort of are the broad areas where you think
componenttext: But looking at the future acquisitions, I think, Bill, you said mentioned that you don't see yourself doing anything, Agilent doing anything significant for the next six months. But in terms of priorities, which sort of are the broad areas where you think that you would be more active and looking at either consolidating transactions or enhancing the portfolio? And also, how are you looking at acquisitions now? What are the metrics you're looking for?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we've been very public about this. Our number one priority is to continue to expand our Life Science portfolio. We will continue to invest in the applied chemical markets, particularly on the consumables side, and we believe those are the largest marke
componenttext: So we've been very public about this. Our number one priority is to continue to expand our Life Science portfolio. We will continue to invest in the applied chemical markets, particularly on the consumables side, and we believe those are the largest markets and largest opportunity. And particularly given our strong market position already in Electronic Measurement, our criteria for acquisition remains the same. We are absolutely committed to drive value for our shareholders. The acquisitions have to be accretive in year one and of course have to be able to drive something that's above our return on capital and get back to our long-term operating model of 20% over time. So we have not changed our criteria and we will continue to look for opportunities to expand our analytical product offerings and consumables.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there something that is relatively small that could be on the cards? Or is your focus on mid-to-large-sized acquisitions? You mentioned that there's nothing large for the next six months, but is there a pipeline for smaller sort of bolt-ons?
componenttext: And is there something that is relatively small that could be on the cards? Or is your focus on mid-to-large-sized acquisitions? You mentioned that there's nothing large for the next six months, but is there a pipeline for smaller sort of bolt-ons?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, we've made 21 smaller acquisitions over the last five years, and so we'll continue to make those types of acquisitions. They tend to be technology-based get quickly integrated into our businesses moving forward. So yes, we'll continue to do t
componenttext: As you know, we've made 21 smaller acquisitions over the last five years, and so we'll continue to make those types of acquisitions. They tend to be technology-based get quickly integrated into our businesses moving forward. So yes, we'll continue to do those, but they're not going to be material short term to the company.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Anthony Luscri for Mark. Quick question on your Communications revenues in the current quarter. I see that you've been running it at about 17% to 18% run rate over the last couple of quarters. And when you add up those, the last couple of quarters
componenttext: This is Anthony Luscri for Mark. Quick question on your Communications revenues in the current quarter. I see that you've been running it at about 17% to 18% run rate over the last couple of quarters. And when you add up those, the last couple of quarters on the slide that you presented, it's 20%. So that's pretty significant jump. Is that all LTE-related and am I reading that correctly?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: A lot of the growth is just a re-emergence of investments in, as Ron said, in manufacturing. As you know, smartphones, the actual number of units have gone up and the expansion in China with their 3G rollout, plus the LTE R&D investment.
componenttext: A lot of the growth is just a re-emergence of investments in, as Ron said, in manufacturing. As you know, smartphones, the actual number of units have gone up and the expansion in China with their 3G rollout, plus the LTE R&D investment.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then for the outlook for the fiscal year '11 with EMG, can you speak to some of the secular drivers within the segments that you play outside of LTE beyond just the Agilent strength such the strong product portfolio and market share gains the you're s
componenttext: And then for the outlook for the fiscal year '11 with EMG, can you speak to some of the secular drivers within the segments that you play outside of LTE beyond just the Agilent strength such the strong product portfolio and market share gains the you're seeing?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that overall, we believe Aerospace and Defense business will continue to grow next year. Our business outside the U.S. continues to be robust. The efforts that we have made in operational surveillance has continue to do very, very well. And w
componenttext: Yes, I think that overall, we believe Aerospace and Defense business will continue to grow next year. Our business outside the U.S. continues to be robust. The efforts that we have made in operational surveillance has continue to do very, very well. And we made recent public statements, we've done very good job of winning very large tender offers in the U.S. Military. And if you look at the DoD budget, there is no evidence of any severe cutback in 2011. Yes, refocus of priorities but the fundamental investment we believe will not be a material change. Communications, we talked about, it's all about the growth in the wireless and the continued investment in LTE. In the Industrial and Computers, all going to be driven by the macroeconomic environment. Yes, we have a great product portfolio in there, but the major drivers continued investment in capital investment. So the a new areas we have noted is that in the Semiconductor business, will there be an isotope as the capacity catches up with demand moving forward. But as I said to a previous question, roughly, we have about $100 million that's kind of caught in what would be your typical Semiconductor Cap business. So again, not super material to the outcome of the company.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And today's final question is a follow-up from the line of William Stein with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And today's final question is a follow-up from the line of William Stein with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Something we haven't spoken about on this call I think or at least I haven't heard it is stimulus spending and how that's impacted your business so far, and whether there's much left to benefit the company. Bill, can you give us some ideas as to how that'
componenttext: Something we haven't spoken about on this call I think or at least I haven't heard it is stimulus spending and how that's impacted your business so far, and whether there's much left to benefit the company. Bill, can you give us some ideas as to how that's helped or not helped the company?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will give a broad editorial, which I've said quite publically, and then I'll have Nick give you comment, that's for a lot of the big NIH funding is going. Governments around the world had basically invested over $2 trillion in stimulus money in var
componenttext: Yes, I will give a broad editorial, which I've said quite publically, and then I'll have Nick give you comment, that's for a lot of the big NIH funding is going. Governments around the world had basically invested over $2 trillion in stimulus money in various ways. It is my firm belief irregardless of one's political presentation that $2 trillion will in fact have an impact. You'll see the stimulus money that went into China, they have the capability to do it again. Nick comment on the stimulus money in the U.S. Every country does it a little bit differently. And so it really is hard to track. But that investment is not only stopping the financial crisis in 2009, but in fact putting more money into academic research and across the board has had I think a positive impact very, very hard to quantify that outside of big areas like NIH.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Nick. We still see this money out there flowing. It's just flowing slowly and it's coming out because of the way they put it in the system. This is not just the U.S. comment, but certainly in the U.S. the money is starting to flow. It's really not
componenttext: This is Nick. We still see this money out there flowing. It's just flowing slowly and it's coming out because of the way they put it in the system. This is not just the U.S. comment, but certainly in the U.S. the money is starting to flow. It's really not going to have a huge impact for Agilent. And we think actually it's going to have a smoothing impact on a couple of year basis around the globe.  You've seen us made some comments about some money coming out of Malaysia. We're seeing money in Southeast Asia. And these monies will continue to flow as governments invest in healthcare and in life science research. And so we hope to catch our share, but we don't think you're going to see any big bumps nor our big stops.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the fourth quarter 2010 Agilent Technologies Incorporated earnings conference call. My name is Keisha and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all lines are on listen-only mode. We will conduct a q
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the fourth quarter 2010 Agilent Technologies Incorporated earnings conference call. My name is Keisha and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all lines are on listen-only mode. We will conduct a question-and-answer session towards the end of this conference.
I’d now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Ms. Alicia Rodriguez, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keisha and welcome everyone to Agilent’s fourth quarter conference call for fiscal year 2010. With me are Agilent’s President and CEO, Bill Sullivan, as well as Senior Vice President and CFO, Didier Hirsch. Joining in our Q&A will be the Pr
componenttext:
Thank you, Keisha and welcome everyone to Agilent’s fourth quarter conference call for fiscal year 2010. With me are Agilent’s President and CEO, Bill Sullivan, as well as Senior Vice President and CFO, Didier Hirsch. Joining in our Q&A will be the Presidents of Agilent’s Electronic Measurement, Life Sciences, and Chemical Analysis Group’s Ron Nersesian, Nick Roelofs, and Mike McMullen.
After my comments, Bill will give his perspective on the quarter and the overall market environment. Didier will then follow with the review of financial results and after Didier’s comments, we will open the lines and take your questions.
In case you haven’t had a chance to review our press release, you can find it on our Web site at www.investor.agilent.com. Please note that the business segment financial tables are in the schedules that accompanying the press release.
We are also providing further information to supplement today’s discussion. After you log on to our webcast module from our Web site, please click on the link for supporting material. There you will find additional information such as our revenue breakouts and historical financial information for Agilent’s continuing operations.
Also, in accordance with SEC Regulation G, if during this conference call we use any non-GAAP financial measures, you will find on our Web site the required reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial metric.
Additionally, I’d like to remind you that we will make forward-looking statements about the future financial performance of the company. These involve risks and uncertainties that could cause Agilent’s results to differ materially from management’s current expectations. As a result, we encourage you to look at the company’s most recent filings with the SEC to get a more complete picture of all the factors at work.
The forward-looking statements, including our guidance provided today during the call are only valid as of this date and the company assumes no obligation to update such statements as we move throughout the current quarter.
Now, let me turn the call over to Bill for his comments.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alicia and hello everyone. Agilent’s latest results continue to build on the strong momentum that we have seen throughout fiscal 2010. There are three major themes that have emerged. One, we have successfully completed the transformation of Agil
componenttext:
Thanks, Alicia and hello everyone. Agilent’s latest results continue to build on the strong momentum that we have seen throughout fiscal 2010. There are three major themes that have emerged. One, we have successfully completed the transformation of Agilent. Two, the Varian integration is going exceedingly well. Three, we are benefiting from strong organic growth as a result of the regional sales support expansion and technology investments we have made.
Fourth quarter orders of $1.7 billion were up 32% year-over-year, while revenues of $1.6 billion were up 36% from a year ago. Note that these numbers include the results of the Varian acquisition. Without the Varian acquisition and recent divestitures, orders and revenues were up 23% and 26% respectively.
In addition to the top line growth, our Q4 non-GAAP earnings were more than double to $228 million or $0.65 per share from a year ago. Agilent’s fourth quarter revenue growth was strong across all regions. Excluding acquisitions and divestitures, the Americas were up 23% year-over-year, Europe was up 13% and Asia Pacific was up 38%.
On November 1, we successfully reached a major milestone in the integration of the Varian acquisition. This includes combining all Agilent and Varian legal entities and moving Varian employees to Agilent’s pay and benefits. Agilent and Varian now appears as one single company to our customers.
We now have one Web site, unified call centers, a combined field organization and a single service and support process for our customers. Quotations, orders and invoices are all common for Agilent and Varian products.
Moving forward, our priority is to continue to drive revenue and cost synergies, as well as to drive technology sharing between the divisions and business groups. We now believe that we will achieve $100 million in net savings. This is inclusive of $10 million of additional R&D we’re investing in Varian’s technologies as well as our increased investment in service and support. From a market perspective, our fourth quarter results saw continued strength in our key markets and geographies.
In our Chemical Analysis business, we saw sustained growth across all market segments. Q4 revenues of $389 million were up 73% over last year, up 17% excluding Varian. Operating margin, including Varian, was 22%. The energy and petrochemical markets continue to recover, while food and environmental markets remained strong around the world.
From a product perspective, our new product introduction of GC/MS, ICP-MS and GC Triple Quad continue to drive strong interest in growth in food and environmental applications and the 5975 Transportable MSD which was introduced to Pittcon is getting significant interest from government sector.
In our Life Science business, revenues of $431 million were up 35% over last year. Not including Varian in a high core divestiture, Life Science revenues hit an all-time high growing 17% compared to Q4 2009. Operating margin, including Varian, was 14%.
Academic and government revenues grew 31% over last year on an organic basis. The academic market remains solid particularly in light of U.S. stimulus and growth in China.
We saw 14% year-over-year organic growth in pharma and biotech. The market continues to face a paradigm shift as companies continue to restructure, outsource and move to low-cost locations. We are well positioned to take advantage of the pharma’s shift to developing countries.
From a product perspective, platform growth was strong across the board with Life Science platforms all growing by double-digits year-over-year. LC revenues, led by our 1290 and 1260 products, were up 21% year-over-year. LC/MS and Genomics, including our SureSelect products, continue to perform very well.
In Electronic Measurement, revenue of $764 million, were up 24% from a year ago. Excluding the Network Solutions divestitures, revenues grew 35%. Operating margin was 20%. Aerospace and defense was up 16%, while revenues from industrial, computer and semiconductor customers grew 43% from a year ago. Electronic industry growth continues to be strong and outpace general economic growth.
Key drivers continue to be business investment and emerging economic expansion. Excluding the Network Solutions divestitures, communication revenues were up 41% over last year. 3G technologies continue to dominate expanding in both wireless manufacturing and wireless R&D. Our key investment is focused on R&D and continues to grow.
Geographically, all regions saw a year-over-year increase led by Asia, which contributed half electronic measurements dollar growth. From our platform perspective, we have our strongest product lineup in years. Our PNA-X network analyzer, PXA signal analyzers and PSG Signal Generators, all continue to drive growth and outperform our competitors.
Our scope business was up 39% year-over-year. We’re continuing to gaining share with our high-performance of solar scopes led by the success of our Infiniium X-Series and we introduced 48 new module instrument products in Q4. Moving forward, we continue to see numerous market opportunities and we believe Agilent is in strong position to capitalize on them.
There are four major areas where we differentiate ourselves. First is our market reach and customer trust, where we continue to invest in customer service and support. We are paying special attentions to supporting our continued growth in Asia.
Second, is our technology leadership while we are currently have the leading technology in every one of our core platforms, we will maintain R&D investment 11% of revenue in fiscal year ‘11.
We continue to believe that our above industry average R&D investment will maintain our technology leadership across all major products. In addition, it will fund strategic initiatives as Life Sciences, Operational surveillance in Nano technology. We plan to release many exciting new products in 2011.
Third is our scale and scope, we currently have among the lowest instrument cost of sales in the industry. At the same time, we maintain our stellar reputation for quality and reliability. Our global manufacturing capability is second to none.
As we move into 2011, we plan to drive substantial improvements in cost of sales across all variant portfolios, as well as improve cost of sales across the balance of our Analytical product portfolio.
For example, we have recently opened our new LC/MS factory in Singapore. We plan to transfer RF console manufacturing for NMR to Penang. We will shut down our Walnut Creek facility in consolidated with other Agilent facilities. We will move machine tooling out of our Australia facility and will continue to leverage the scale of our procurement and logistics operations.
The fourth way we differentiate ourselves is our team. Our 18,500 employees remain focused externally on our customers and our market opportunities. We are in a strong position moving into the new fiscal year.
For the first quarter of 2011, we expect revenues in the range of $1.53 billion to $1.55 billion. Non-GAAP earnings are expected to be in the range of $0.55 to $0.57 per share. For the full fiscal year 2011, we expect revenue to range from $1.6 billion to $6.3 billion and non-GAAP earnings of $2.30 to $2.50 per share.
Thank you for being on the call, and now, I’ll turn it over to Didier.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill and good morning, everyone. I’ll start by providing additional color on our fourth quarter results and then comment on our outlook for Q1 and the new fiscal year. All my comments will refer to non-GAAP figures, so, starting with Q4 resul
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill and good morning, everyone. I’ll start by providing additional color on our fourth quarter results and then comment on our outlook for Q1 and the new fiscal year. All my comments will refer to non-GAAP figures, so, starting with Q4 results.
As Bill mentioned, Agilent delivered a very solid fourth quarter performance. Orders of $1.7 billion were up 32% from one year ago both in dollars and local currency, with Asia-Pacific up 40%, the Americas up 27% and Europe up 31%. Orders grew 23% on an organic basis. Revenues of $1.6 billion were up 36% in dollars and local currency from one year ago or 26% on an organic basis.
All three business segments generated strong double-digit revenue growth, both in total and organically. Geographic revenue was on an organic basis increased 38% in Asia-Pacific and grew 23% in the Americas and 13% in Europe. Organic revenue growth in China was 37%, while India revenue grew 31%.
Now moving to the income statement, fourth quarter non-GAAP operating profit of $303 million improved a $153 million from one year ago, on a $470 million increase in revenues, a 37% operating margin incremental. Excluding Varian, the year-over-year operating margin incremental was 63%, with all three segments delivering very sound operating margin incremental on an organic basis.
The story of this outstanding year-over-year performance remains the same as last quarter, as we saw strong top line revenue growth, coupled with markedly lower cost structure that was created through our restructuring programs completed earlier in the year. Currency had minimal impact on any of the income statement line items.
Now turning to the individual income statement line items, fourth quarter gross margins of 55.3% were essentially flat from last year. Excluding Varian, gross margins of 57.1% improved by 1.5 points over last year. We did recognize a few non-recurring cost in Q4 that reduced gross margins by about 0.5 points.
Fourth quarter operating expenses increased $73 million year-over-year, primarily due to the Varian acquisition. Wage restoration and higher variable incentive pay were offset by restructuring savings.
Operating profit of $303 million more than doubled from the same period last year. Agilent’s fourth quarter operating margin was 19%, an increase of six points from one year ago and our highest operating margin performance ever. Net other income and other expense declined $12 million from last year due to higher interest expenses.
However, we plan to retire the $1.5 billion World Trade debt on December 1, two months earlier than planned, which will reduce our interest expense by over $2 million per month starting in December.
Moving to taxes, note that our non-GAAP tax rate will remain at 19% in fiscal year 2011. We expect our non-GAAP tax rate to further decline to 18% in fiscal year ‘12 in conjunction with the completion of the Varian integration.
Non-GAAP net income of $228 million or $0.65 per share compares to $111 million and $0.32 per share one year ago. Both quarterly earnings per share and full year EPS of $2 are a record high for Agilent.
Now, turning to the cash flow and the balance sheet, we continue to demonstrate discipline in asset management. Inventory days on hand of 92 days were five days better than one year ago. Receivables days sales outstanding increased three days from one year ago to 49 days due to Varian higher days sales outstanding.
Total cash from operations was $367 million, an increase of $164 million from one year ago. During the quarter, we received $37 million from employee stock programs and repurchased $51 million worth of shares. Year-to-date, we have received $301 million and repurchased $410 million.
We will continue the present buyback program intended to keep the basic outstanding share count at 346 million shares. This anti-dilutive share buyback program will utilize about $120 million in cash in fiscal year ‘11. Based on the present stock price, you should assume 356 million diluted shares throughout fiscal year ‘11.
With regards to net cash, we finished the quarter with net cash of $598 million. Now, turning to the fiscal year 2011 outlook, you’ll recall that last quarter, we provided two scenarios that bracketed the range of analyst estimates, with a revenue range of $5.9 billion on the low end and $6.2 billion on the high-end and EPS of $2.15 to $2.50, which was based on 352 million diluted shares.
We’re now increasing our fiscal year ‘11 revenue guidance range to $6.1 billion to $6.3 billion and EPS of $2.30 to $2.50 based on 356 million diluted shares.
With this new guidance, we’re raising the low end of the revenue range by $200 million and $0.15 for EPS and the high end of the revenue range by $100 million with no change in EPS.
We’re holding to the high end of the EPS range, as more than half of the projected revenue increase is due to currency changes that provide minimal incremental operating profit. In addition, we are selectively investing about $20 million on revenue generating projects and activities.
Finally, the 4 million share increase in diluted shares reduces EPS by $0.03. You will note that the mid-point of our revenue guidance, $6.2 billion, translates into 13% year-over-year growth or 8% growth on an organic basis. The mid-point of our EPS guidance, $2.40 translates into 20% growth over our fiscal year ‘10 EPS of $2.
Here are few other items to keep in mind as you update your models for fiscal year ‘11. Annual salary increases will be effective December 1, 2010. Stock-based compensation will be about $73 million compared to $66 million in fiscal year ‘10 and as we frontload the recognition of stock-based compensation, the Q1 expense will be about $26 million.
Third, we expect operating cash flow of approximately $950 million and capital expenditures of about $150 million, which yield free cash flow of approximately $800 million.
Fourth, we distribute our variable pay and incentive pay in Q1 and Q3. Hence, Q2 and Q4 are seasonally higher cash flow quarters. Depreciation and amortization are projected to be $150 million for the fiscal year.
Finally, moving to the guidance for first quarter, we expect Q1 revenues of $1.530 billion to $1.550 billion and EPS of $0.55 to $0.57. On the mid-point, year-over-year revenue growth will be 27% or 16% on an organic basis. The mid-point of our EPS guidance corresponds to year-over-year EPS growth of 47%.
As you consider the projected decline in EPS from Q4 to Q1, you will want to keep in mind the impact of the December salary increase, frontloading of stock-based compensation and the increase in payroll taxes due to the disbursement of our second half fiscal year ‘10 variable and incentive pay.
With that, I’ll turn it over to Alicia for the Q&A.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jon, thanks for the question. Given our portfolio, we’re still seeing the same dynamic which is, investment is lighting up in places like India, Korea, in fact, we were a little bit positively surprised this quarter at pharma’s strength in the U.
componenttext:
Yes, Jon, thanks for the question. Given our portfolio, we’re still seeing the same dynamic which is, investment is lighting up in places like India, Korea, in fact, we were a little bit positively surprised this quarter at pharma’s strength in the U.S. Europe is going to remain soft. If you dig underneath that, what you see is this continued transformation of NCE to NBE, plus the surprises we’re seeing in the U.S. are really a recycle of the replacement market, so that’s starting.
We’re going to see replacement in G-8 countries from big pharma on top of our natural trend that we’ve been talking about for several quarters. So, we think it’s going to be pretty good. You saw our 14% number this quarter, this was a hot quarter. But we think it’s going to be a pretty year for us in our space in pharma.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then last one for Bill. Bill, if we look at the capital deployment scenarios in FY ‘11, is it reasonable to assume that there is no M&A come in the second half of ‘11 that that buyback number could be higher than the base case assumption of $120 m
componenttext: And then last one for Bill. Bill, if we look at the capital deployment scenarios in FY ‘11, is it reasonable to assume that there is no M&A come in the second half of ‘11 that that buyback number could be higher than the base case assumption of $120 million?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: As Didier said, I think you should assume the guidance that we have given. Our top priority right now is to pay back the world trade debt that will drive our EPS growth. The big issue we have is continued repatriation of cash back into the U.S. and so obv
componenttext: As Didier said, I think you should assume the guidance that we have given. Our top priority right now is to pay back the world trade debt that will drive our EPS growth. The big issue we have is continued repatriation of cash back into the U.S. and so obviously, if the environment changes or just the normal course of business that we can get more cash in the U.S. one might consider that. But right now, I would assume for 2011 that we will pay off the debt and maintain the share count as Didier outlined.

Thanks very much. Two questions; one is, what do you see with respect to commodity price elevation and how is that affecting your cost of goods, are you able to actually get some pricing through to the end customer, as it relates to that elevated cost of goods?
Second question is, much like the previous, could you frame the relative end-markets from the low end scenario to the high end scenario, what would a low end scenario end-market look like or among the businesses and what would a higher end scenario from those end-markets outlooks look like?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of cost, I’m going to let Ron make a comment on this because he’s by far the bigger user of components. Overall, the component shortage is clearly subsiding, and that availability of components has been better and of course, if you look at ou
componenttext: In terms of cost, I’m going to let Ron make a comment on this because he’s by far the bigger user of components. Overall, the component shortage is clearly subsiding, and that availability of components has been better and of course, if you look at our cost to sales as DDA ex-Varian, we’re obviously able to compensate for that. But I will let Ron get some commentary just on the availability in pricing?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at our gross margin for the last year, we had actually the highest gross margin that we’ve ever seen in the last decade in fiscal year ‘10 at 58%. So, overall our gross margin is doing very well. We do not see material price inflation. Our
componenttext: If you look at our gross margin for the last year, we had actually the highest gross margin that we’ve ever seen in the last decade in fiscal year ‘10 at 58%. So, overall our gross margin is doing very well. We do not see material price inflation. Our cost reduction programs are offsetting that and we do not anticipate there to be a big issue.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to conclude, the work that we are going to do on improving the Varian cost of sales I think is just going to overwhelm any increase of a component part costs.In terms of your second question I guess, again the low end is the guidance that we gave a
componenttext:
Just to conclude, the work that we are going to do on improving the Varian cost of sales I think is just going to overwhelm any increase of a component part costs.
In terms of your second question I guess, again the low end is the guidance that we gave at $6.1 billion. We have enormous momentum going into 2011. Our backlog has grown. The order rate of $1.7 billion in Q4 again continued to have very solid greater than one book to build.
So, the big wildcard is the second half of 2011. We have assumed in this plan that growth in the U.S. and Europe and Japan would be at best at 2%, it could be lower than that aggregately. We still believe that there is opportunity in emerging markets obviously, China and India.
We also see opportunity in Latin America, driven by Brazil and a continued growth through some of the other countries in Southeast Asia. So, we think we have a very balanced portfolio coupled with that, we say, we’re going to maintain our position as a technology leader. I still believe that almost any scenario that customers will be able to play for differential measurement solutions.
