headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. I’m wondering if we can dig into Varian a little bit. I apologize if this was addressed on the call, I joined a bit late. Can you help us understand how far along the company is in terms of integrating the business and capturing some of th
componenttext: Thanks, Bill. I’m wondering if we can dig into Varian a little bit. I apologize if this was addressed on the call, I joined a bit late. Can you help us understand how far along the company is in terms of integrating the business and capturing some of the revenue decline that we saw with that business before the acquisition was completed, and then also from the perspective of the cost savings, how far along we are in that process today?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, the good news in the quarter for Varian is, the revenue was, I believe roughly $192 million. So, after a slow start in Q3, we obviously made a big recovery in Q4, and so we’re quite pleased with the momentum that we have going into 2011, so that’s
componenttext:
So, the good news in the quarter for Varian is, the revenue was, I believe roughly $192 million. So, after a slow start in Q3, we obviously made a big recovery in Q4, and so we’re quite pleased with the momentum that we have going into 2011, so that’s good news. The opportunity continues to be the cost of sales. I did outline in the call that we have a taken various steps. I announced the closure of the Walnut Creek facility and consolidating it to other Agilent locations.
We’ve announced the transfer of the RF consoles to Penang and gained to leverage our EMG capability there. We continue to look at opportunities to leverage our procurement and operations and this last weekend we went live with essentially quote to cash process, so that we have an invoice process that’s one with Agilent and that is going exceedingly well. All 3,000 employees essentially have been transferred over to the Agilent pay and benefits. So again, from my perspective, the integration is going spectacularly well.
The big long-term issue and again I’ll have Mike make a comment and then Nick is to really take the additional R&D spending that we’re making to be able to expand and to upgrade the Varian platform in conjunction with our effort to reduce the cost of sales. This, of course, takes time, it’s not going to be done overnight, but we have very, very solid plans to drive the Varian cost of sales to Agilent standards.
And in fact, in my opening comments said that we’re raising the $75 million of cost synergies to $100 million. So we’re just getting a lot better handle on that, and I’m very pleased with the revenue growth that we’ve got Q3 to Q4 sequentially in Varian. So, Mike, do you want to make a comment about Varian.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Bill, I like to really focus my comments on two areas. First of all, building on Bill’s comments around the integration of the team, on the field side, we now have a fully integrated field organization and what we may not have been communicat
componenttext:
Yes. Sure, Bill, I like to really focus my comments on two areas. First of all, building on Bill’s comments around the integration of the team, on the field side, we now have a fully integrated field organization and what we may not have been communicating previously is we actually have been making a series of investment to further build out the resources in targeted areas, where we see grow. Majority of those hires have been completed, training has been done and really well-positioned, as we go into FY ‘11 from a field capability and resource side.
As Bill mentioned earlier, the portfolio is a key aspect of the go-forward business and what I mean by that is we have doubled down on our R&D and have a number of very aggressive programs to refresh and enhance the portfolio, so you should expect to see us coming out with new offerings in the coming quarters.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: A lot of questions came in yesterday to me following Cisco’s results and their commentary on weak spending by state and local governments. Can you give us just a brief comment on whether you are seeing any weakness related to that in either of the three
componenttext: A lot of questions came in yesterday to me following Cisco’s results and their commentary on weak spending by state and local governments. Can you give us just a brief comment on whether you are seeing any weakness related to that in either of the three segments, I should say, the federal, state or your local level.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its good comment. Well, if you don’t mind. I’m going to add. Nick just made a comment about the NMR business, and I think it’s really important. He said that was the product line that quite frankly, we need to make the investment, but secondly, it r
componenttext: Its good comment. Well, if you don’t mind. I’m going to add. Nick just made a comment about the NMR business, and I think it’s really important. He said that was the product line that quite frankly, we need to make the investment, but secondly, it really allows us to leverage our RF capabilities. I think it’s important to have Nick make a comment about that. And then I’ll answer your question about the government spending.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Will, this is back to, of course, your first question. Really in the Varian research products business, first, we saw the strongest orders and the strongest revenue in history of that business, and I think the orders is a compliment to the fact that the c
componenttext:
Will, this is back to, of course, your first question. Really in the Varian research products business, first, we saw the strongest orders and the strongest revenue in history of that business, and I think the orders is a compliment to the fact that the customer base is seeing us invest in sales guys and service guys and seeing that team starting to get trained, now that we’re two quarters in and they have the confidence that we will really be there for them to service. They obviously can’t yet see the investments we’re doing in R&D, but that’s the other side of the same equation which is, we have real confidence that we can put some momentum in to cost of goods of the product, both with breakthrough technology from the RF capabilities of EMG.
But, also as Bill mentioned, we are moving our console to be close to, actually on top of EMG manufacturing site in Penang and that will give us cost to goods as well as proximity to accelerate getting those R&D improvements into the product mix.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of government and again I might have Mike make comment about forensics environment, it is the classic ones that are government. But from the DOD perspective which by far the biggest government, our growth rate was 17% year-over-year, 8% sequentia
componenttext:
In terms of government and again I might have Mike make comment about forensics environment, it is the classic ones that are government. But from the DOD perspective which by far the biggest government, our growth rate was 17% year-over-year, 8% sequentially so, our aerospace and defense business continues to do quite well, that’s obvious and I talked about this quite publicly.
It is that, one of the bigger concerns that we have had in terms of will there be a major cutback in the U.S. given that’s half the market and to-date, we continue to do very well with leading products in that. The DOD budget for next year, in fact, is I believe up 4% and we continue to do well in other countries, outside the U.S. So, Mike you may want to comment on the environmental and forensics which is another heavily government purchased commodities?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Bill, this is kind of story here from a Chemical Analysis growth perspective. We’ve actually seen continued strength in the government sector, both in U.S., China and other emerging countries. I think you saw in our announcement, for example,
componenttext:
Yes. Sure, Bill, this is kind of story here from a Chemical Analysis growth perspective. We’ve actually seen continued strength in the government sector, both in U.S., China and other emerging countries. I think you saw in our announcement, for example, of some of the success we’ve had with the recently introduced transportable GCMS product. It is one more indication of the willingness to invest in areas that are of quite of an interest to in the public sector whether it be food safety and whether it be in environmental hazards that may exist in the local community.
So, we’ve actually seen continued strength from a government level of funding throughout this quarter and expect to see that continue into FY’11. By the way, the state forensic level spending in U.S. has been depressed, and we’re not really counting on a major recovery there. But overall the government-driven spending in our business has been solid and we continue to expect it to be robust.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. Thanks, guys.
componenttext: Very helpful. Thanks, guys.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks for taking the question. I’ll be brief. Just first source of all, Didier, did you explained why the share count is going up, I think you said you’re going to try and keep it flat everything its up $4 million, is that reflection of the share
componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking the question. I’ll be brief. Just first source of all, Didier, did you explained why the share count is going up, I think you said you’re going to try and keep it flat everything its up $4 million, is that reflection of the share price or?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly. We’re keeping the basic share count outstanding of 346 million shares. This one we really control. The diluted share count, we do not control because it’s very much impacted by the share price. With a significant increase in the share co
componenttext: Yes, exactly. We’re keeping the basic share count outstanding of 346 million shares. This one we really control. The diluted share count, we do not control because it’s very much impacted by the share price. With a significant increase in the share count now we are seeing at $35 or $36, we computed that our diluted share count would be about what I say 356 million shares. Even as the basic outstanding share counts which we control will remain at 346, which is the intent of the program.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there some rule of thumb, if I give a stock price for like 40 instead of 35, like what does that due to the diluted share count?
componenttext: Is there some rule of thumb, if I give a stock price for like 40 instead of 35, like what does that due to the diluted share count?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean our diluted share count this year has been between 350 and now it’s 356, so you can map that to the change in the share price. But it could change over time depending on obviously, when those stock options invest and things like that. So, but yes
componenttext: I mean our diluted share count this year has been between 350 and now it’s 356, so you can map that to the change in the share price. But it could change over time depending on obviously, when those stock options invest and things like that. So, but yes that’s about that. Our share price has been between about $27 and $36 and our diluted share count between 350 million and 356 million.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you can, I don’t know, Bill or if Ron wants to answer this question, but you’re doing 20% operating margins in EM right now. It looks like you still see continued momentum in that business. Any update in terms of kind of the operating model for tha
componenttext: If you can, I don’t know, Bill or if Ron wants to answer this question, but you’re doing 20% operating margins in EM right now. It looks like you still see continued momentum in that business. Any update in terms of kind of the operating model for that business?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’ve got a lot of momentum and I’ll have Ron answer your question.
componenttext: We’ve got a lot of momentum and I’ll have Ron answer your question.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We obviously feel very, very comfortable with the model that we have outlaid and we’ve been outperforming with the 58% incremental during this past year. With the cost structure that we have, we are maintaining what we had planned, and we’re capturing
componenttext:
We obviously feel very, very comfortable with the model that we have outlaid and we’ve been outperforming with the 58% incremental during this past year. With the cost structure that we have, we are maintaining what we had planned, and we’re capturing upside, for instance, in the oscilloscope market, we had mentioned that we had 39% revenue growth, but if we look at the last quarter, our order growth was over 70%.
We also had record high performance scopes, record high sampling scopes, all regions were over 50% growth, and we had record high unit growth. So there is a lot of things that is helping us drive great incrementals in the business and over 40% incrementals as we go forward, but we feel very comfortable with the guidance that we’ve given that we’ll be able to meet or exceed that guidance.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, EMG, as you know has targeted to have the high end of our increment, 30% to 40% increment and as Ron just said absolutely committed to do that and all the incentives are in place to reward that result.
componenttext: Again, EMG, as you know has targeted to have the high end of our increment, 30% to 40% increment and as Ron just said absolutely committed to do that and all the incentives are in place to reward that result.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on EM on the order growth, we’ve heard previously that you’ve been doing some discussions in businesses that there is a big replacement or the potential for a big replacement cycle we’ve talked about on the LC side a lot, b
componenttext: If I could just follow up on EM on the order growth, we’ve heard previously that you’ve been doing some discussions in businesses that there is a big replacement or the potential for a big replacement cycle we’ve talked about on the LC side a lot, but maybe not as much on the EM side just given the advances that are being made and there’s technological requirements whether be in some of the optics or in some of the buses. Is a growth just to rebound still or are you seeing like a replacement that you need new oscilloscopes that have higher speeds etc., and there needs to be a replacement that goes on to be able to keep up with the demand? Thanks.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The oscilloscope market, in particular, the real-time oscilloscope market really continues to grow because there continues to be new technology and new bus speeds that demands higher and higher speeds as the bandwidth needs are insatiable. So that will al
componenttext:
The oscilloscope market, in particular, the real-time oscilloscope market really continues to grow because there continues to be new technology and new bus speeds that demands higher and higher speeds as the bandwidth needs are insatiable. So that will always continue to go on and we’ve seen that continuously.
On the overall wireless area, we’re seeing the smartphone growth really explode, where we saw over 70% unit growth for the industry and we’ve also seen the adoption rate of 3G phones continue to increase to about 24%. So there is a lot of talk about the next replacement generation, which is LTE or fourth quarter generation that is happening, but as Bill mentioned, that’s mostly in R&D, and we’re seeing some infrastructure growth, although you won’t see a lot of infrastructure growth till 2011, and more particularly, 2012 and 2013. So the fundamentals are very good, but it’s not going to be an instantaneous stair step up.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ron.
componenttext: Thanks, Ron.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken representing Deutsche Bank. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken representing Deutsche Bank. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, guys. This is Vijay [ph] in for Ross. Congrats on nice quarter. I just wanted to dig in on the defense part, there was a press article out there in Wall Street Journal yesterday as part of the deficit-reduction commission support, talking about may b
componenttext: Hey, guys. This is Vijay [ph] in for Ross. Congrats on nice quarter. I just wanted to dig in on the defense part, there was a press article out there in Wall Street Journal yesterday as part of the deficit-reduction commission support, talking about may be $100 billion reduction in defense budgets. Just to be sure, on the defense budgets, the way to think about it is aerospace defense and surveillance equipments is where the incremental growth is coming in. So, in general, the headline news like $100 billion reduction does not necessarily translate to weakness on the defense side, is that right?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, I will again have Ron make a comment about some of the sectors, particularly operational surveillance as you just referenced. Again, I am very open about it in the last year. If you look at what risk is, the risk is will there be a substantial
componenttext:
Absolutely, I will again have Ron make a comment about some of the sectors, particularly operational surveillance as you just referenced. Again, I am very open about it in the last year. If you look at what risk is, the risk is will there be a substantial cutbacks in defense spending given the budget issues in the U.S. To-date that has not happened, the budget for next year has not been cut. The recommendation $100 million is from the Task Force that the President had set up to figure out where are ways that the country can cut back on expenses.
My own personal opinion is short-term, given the employment issues, not obvious to me that those decision are going to made, but what we need to do is make sure that we have the right products for the next-generation radar system, missile systems that we can make a contribution and the operational surveillances is just a real obvious place, where both parties fully support. So, I will let Ron give you an update on where we are in operational surveillance.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, on operational surveillance we are seeing exceptional growth on the network side, where there is surveillance on the network side and in particular, we’ve seen over 100% growth during the last year and seeing that business move from investment mode
componenttext: Yes, on operational surveillance we are seeing exceptional growth on the network side, where there is surveillance on the network side and in particular, we’ve seen over 100% growth during the last year and seeing that business move from investment mode to solid double-digit profitability. We continue to see that segment explode and even if there is some type of pullback on new programs overall in defense, we’re seeing very healthy business at maintaining existing systems where Agilent’s installed base and breadth of products is real strong asset. So, we feel very comfortable with the aerospace defense market in general and see some real growth in operational surveillance.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe a quick follow-up on the Life Science segment for Nick. You mentioned that Academic segment was strong. Could you sort of just parse out what you’re seeing in Europe and sort of what’s been the stimulus in backup their and maybe some of your gen
componenttext: Maybe a quick follow-up on the Life Science segment for Nick. You mentioned that Academic segment was strong. Could you sort of just parse out what you’re seeing in Europe and sort of what’s been the stimulus in backup their and maybe some of your genomic, the SureSelect platform and sort of what can we expect going forward?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, the real strength in that Academic segment, a lot of that is coming from investment in Asia, just as a comment. But you hit in the nail in the head, two comments of the subtext. One, in Europe we actually were surprised to see quite a bit of Academic
componenttext:
So, the real strength in that Academic segment, a lot of that is coming from investment in Asia, just as a comment. But you hit in the nail in the head, two comments of the subtext. One, in Europe we actually were surprised to see quite a bit of Academic sector growth in countries like France, Germany, Switzerland and that was really nice seeing them spend some of their money to put in infrastructure in the Academic sector on Life Science.
The big story really is the SureSelect though Genome partitioning in front of next-generation DNA sequencing is really catching fire. You’re starting to see others see that market opportunity as well. We believe we’ve got a tremendous technology leadership position and we believe, therefore, we have a tremendous position in that market and that is growing in Europe, as well as around the world.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a last follow-up on the SureSelect. I mean we’ve heard some nice about competitors getting end products and just given where stimulus is, I mean what’s the expectation? I’m just trying to think second half of ‘11 on what’s the expecta
componenttext: Maybe just a last follow-up on the SureSelect. I mean we’ve heard some nice about competitors getting end products and just given where stimulus is, I mean what’s the expectation? I’m just trying to think second half of ‘11 on what’s the expectations?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is a market where you’ve probably seen this market grow 5X year-over-year as a market and we’re riding it very similar to that growth. So, it’s just a small nascent market that’s now becoming a real piece. I think going forward you’re going
componenttext: This is a market where you’ve probably seen this market grow 5X year-over-year as a market and we’re riding it very similar to that growth. So, it’s just a small nascent market that’s now becoming a real piece. I think going forward you’re going to see the dollar shifting from the reagent piece that is being spent in next-gen sequencing on the instrument to that Genome partitioning and obviously, a lot of people who are going to want to participate. There’s a lot of good tools out there. We do think that we have a technically differentiable solution and by doing partitioning in front of the Genome, you effectively reduce the cost of real data coming out of a Genome because you can do one tenth of the Genome and effectively reduce the price and get all the data you need.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. That’s it from me.
componenttext: Thanks, guys. That’s it from me.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman representing Robert W. Baird. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman representing Robert W. Baird. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Bill and a question for Ron, on the EM side of the business, when you look at I think Didier’s comment that maybe for fiscal ‘11, EM would be up in the 10% organic growth range. If you split EM into two pieces, kind of communications and
componenttext:
Good morning, Bill and a question for Ron, on the EM side of the business, when you look at I think Didier’s comment that maybe for fiscal ‘11, EM would be up in the 10% organic growth range. If you split EM into two pieces, kind of communications and then all else for general purpose, lot of new product flow on the general purpose side, the modular instruments, surveillance.
And Bill you mentioned nanotech and then on communications you have kind of this LTE dynamic underplaying. So, how do you look at those two pieces of the business relative to that 10% organic growth in fiscal ‘11 and how much of that might be new product driven versus end-market recovery?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Richard, we have products that expand both the GP market and the communications market with outside of divestiture grew 41% and 32%. Just to give you an idea, if you look at our core platforms, which include our oscilloscopes or network analyzers, spectru
componenttext:
Richard, we have products that expand both the GP market and the communications market with outside of divestiture grew 41% and 32%. Just to give you an idea, if you look at our core platforms, which include our oscilloscopes or network analyzers, spectrum analyzers and signal sources, they are used in both areas with a little bit more bias of high performance products in the Communications segment. They grew 49% this last quarter.
And we have spent a lot of time over the last three plus years, refreshing those platforms, in particular, when we look at our network analyzers, we introduced the highest performance network analyzers this last quarter, the quarter before, the highest performance real-time oscilloscopes and in the past couple of years, spectrum analyzers and signal sources. So, we see that the refreshing of our portfolio is something that will drive both segments.
Communications, clearly LTE and R&D, as Bill and I had mentioned earlier, will drive things, but there still is very substantial growth in 3G technologies, even particularly in China, where we were one of the first ones to jump on the bandwagon of TD-SCDMA, which is the China standard version for 3G. We’re seeing some healthy growth from our investments, but we don’t see a strong bias one way or the other due to the core platforms that span both segments, Richard.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just, Bill, from the perspective of nanotechnology, some products coming out there, that’s been a growth investment area for you. Is that sized to the point where it can maybe move the growth needle year-over-year for all of EM?
componenttext: Just, Bill, from the perspective of nanotechnology, some products coming out there, that’s been a growth investment area for you. Is that sized to the point where it can maybe move the growth needle year-over-year for all of EM?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. It’s just too big from the core. Again, our AFM or microwave AFM, are continuing to do very well. We introduced scanning electron microscope, benchtop version, but again just given the size of EM, it’s not going to move the needle, but someday wil
componenttext: No. It’s just too big from the core. Again, our AFM or microwave AFM, are continuing to do very well. We introduced scanning electron microscope, benchtop version, but again just given the size of EM, it’s not going to move the needle, but someday will.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, how do you characterize price across the product lines, across the segments. Typically, it takes a form of less discounting, but is price positive contributor year-over-year?
componenttext: Just lastly, how do you characterize price across the product lines, across the segments. Typically, it takes a form of less discounting, but is price positive contributor year-over-year?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it clearly has been not a negative. Every account has a different story moving forward given the snapback and the component shortages. It obviously had a short-term favorable impact on pricing, because of some delivery issues, particularly in EMG.
componenttext:
I think it clearly has been not a negative. Every account has a different story moving forward given the snapback and the component shortages. It obviously had a short-term favorable impact on pricing, because of some delivery issues, particularly in EMG.
So, as you go into a slower market, one assumes that there will be more pricing pressure, but that really is the strength of Agilent. We do have the best gross margins in the industry, we believe from an instrumentation standpoint, and we have very aggressive programs going into 2011 to improve our cost of sales. So, we will be competitive and right now obviously not planning for any degrading of our gross margins.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Luscri representing JPMorgan. Please proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Luscri representing JPMorgan. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. I wanted to focus a little bit more on the gross margin profile in fiscal ‘11. I get the impression that you’ve had a great new product thrust over the last couple of quarters, and I want to see if we compare the mix of the new produ
componenttext: Hi, good morning. I wanted to focus a little bit more on the gross margin profile in fiscal ‘11. I get the impression that you’ve had a great new product thrust over the last couple of quarters, and I want to see if we compare the mix of the new products versus the old, how that impacts gross margin and then how should we view the Varian cost of goods savings as well? So, more or less, is the gross margin profile going to be backend loaded in fiscal ‘11?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: To answer your questions, yes. And again, welcome any of the group Presidents to have a comment, typically our new products are performance leading and the gross margins go up. As we have stated at numerous occasions, we have leadership in every one of ou
componenttext:
To answer your questions, yes. And again, welcome any of the group Presidents to have a comment, typically our new products are performance leading and the gross margins go up. As we have stated at numerous occasions, we have leadership in every one of our major platforms. Offsetting that, of course, we have investment in these new initiatives, but we try to get to profitability as quickly as we can.
The number one task is the Varian product lines. We have a full core press to be able to make that happened, to be able to address that. You’re well aware of the gross margins of Varian, while it was a public company. We have a lot of work to do, but the good news is that we know exactly what needs to get done. The teams are formed and it’s all about executing moving forward.
In addition to that and look at our Life Science business, Nick has already set up our LC/MS manufacturing site in Singapore, we will continue to aggressively balance our manufacturing around the world to ensure that we have very cost competitive products, not compromise reliability or quality, and of course, we have minimized as a result any currency issues. But the task number one is the Varian product lines.
Secondly is our continued focus on driving costs down. We just have a world class team. As you know, we do own our manufacturing guess, we outsource a lot of the PC Board Assembly and so forth, but we have a 100% control and a result of that is that we have continued ongoing value-added engineering to be able to drive costs down and have a program in place to ensure that we can get the best prices from our vendors across all of our product portfolios. Nick?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’d just like to add a little of piece of granularity under two comments Bill made and they both are same comments, which is the Varian piece that is in Life Science and I’m sure Mike may want to comment as well, as Bill said, it’s job one. The rest
componenttext:
I’d just like to add a little of piece of granularity under two comments Bill made and they both are same comments, which is the Varian piece that is in Life Science and I’m sure Mike may want to comment as well, as Bill said, it’s job one. The rest of the portfolio, we’ve had two great years of product launches, but we are still putting a lot of money in R&D.
So on that gross margin side, there is working through the manufacturing structure, those comments are all absolutely spot on, but we’re also putting real R&D investment, not only in our traditional Agilent portfolio, but in the new Varian products, and to the extent that we continue to deliver new differentiable products, we’re going to have really nice performance for the customers and that should keep the gross margin high, and we certainly, coming off two years in a row of beating our record of new product launches numerically, I don’t think we’re done with that kind of cycle.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one further comment from the CAG side relative to this question. I would just reemphasize some of the points that Bill made earlier. We know how to do this. We have a series of defined actionable plans that are being executed right now, and I t
componenttext: Maybe just one further comment from the CAG side relative to this question. I would just reemphasize some of the points that Bill made earlier. We know how to do this. We have a series of defined actionable plans that are being executed right now, and I think you’ll start to see cost coming out in FY ‘11, for example, such as combining logistic centers for example, so eliminating duplicate infrastructures. There are a number of actions that are being taken right now, and we’ll have costs coming out in a next couple of quarters and then as we turn the products, you will see improved gross margin there as well.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the EM side, our strategy has been to one, move more of our business from manufacturing to R&D, which have higher margins; and two, focus on high performance products; and three, add more application software, which has higher gross margins. So again,
componenttext: On the EM side, our strategy has been to one, move more of our business from manufacturing to R&D, which have higher margins; and two, focus on high performance products; and three, add more application software, which has higher gross margins. So again, the move to R&D higher performance products, where performance leadership and application software, are there to offset any type of pricing issues that we see in the manufacturing space.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the last six years, we have shared that one should assume that over a cycle, for example, this is again operating profit not gross margin, is 14%. You should all assume that we are committed to 18% and as you heard, committed to drive as hard as we can
componenttext: In the last six years, we have shared that one should assume that over a cycle, for example, this is again operating profit not gross margin, is 14%. You should all assume that we are committed to 18% and as you heard, committed to drive as hard as we can to hopefully someday update that again.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: A quick follow-up, I noticed in your press release, that you’ve indicated that the Varian integration is on track to meet the targeted revenue synergies I don’t know if missed what that number is. But along those lines are you seeing increased tractio
componenttext: A quick follow-up, I noticed in your press release, that you’ve indicated that the Varian integration is on track to meet the targeted revenue synergies I don’t know if missed what that number is. But along those lines are you seeing increased traction with new customers with the combined entity and how should we view the revenue flow through over the coming years?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had stated publicly that we thought the revenue would be at $800 million as you know in Q3, we were behind that and we had actually lowered what the run rate was going to be effectively to the base in the Q3. What was great about Q4 is that our revenue
componenttext:
We had stated publicly that we thought the revenue would be at $800 million as you know in Q3, we were behind that and we had actually lowered what the run rate was going to be effectively to the base in the Q3. What was great about Q4 is that our revenue as I said was $193 million again this will soon disappear, so we won’t be reporting this after we get through one full year.
We’re very close, close back to the original run rate and then as you can see from the comments that Nick just made regarding NMR and Mike, we’re quite excited to see if we can in fact drive that. We have not made a statement on what that additional opportunity is about the $800 million. But as you can tell, Q4 was just a really solid quarter for those product line and we’re quite excited as we move into 2011.

componenttext: On the $100 million strength in Varian that you step that up now, how do those savings spread out over the next couple of years and is it split basically between how the revenue splits between the two segments or just wanting to get more of the more lion share of the savings that’s possible as we look forward?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, into three buckets, one we call global infrastructure and that will be done in our fiscal year 2011. This is again all of the corporate functions that are being combined. Some of it of course, we’ve already seen just as a result of the combin
componenttext:
Basically, into three buckets, one we call global infrastructure and that will be done in our fiscal year 2011. This is again all of the corporate functions that are being combined. Some of it of course, we’ve already seen just as a result of the combination of the company and the executive team on Varian, essentially leaving the company. From there, the first order is to split it by revenue, but the bias would be on the LSG, the NMR is where we have the biggest cost of sales opportunity and as we have said, we will implement this over the next few years and it’s all about our ability to execute transfer products and get new products into the system, and it’s all about time.
But I’m very, very pleased with the progress that both Mike and Nick have made in terms of addressing that, and again, the alignment with all our 3,000 new employees. They are very excited about both the opportunities in investment and also the understanding the responsibility that we need to improve our gross margins as fast as we can. But I would first order to do it by revenue, a slight bias to LSG and assume this over the next couple of years.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. Thanks for taking the question. Just first off, I’m wondering if you could spend a minute on China and your outlook for that region going forward. I believe there are a couple of government stimulus programs there that could be rolling
componenttext: Hi, good morning. Thanks for taking the question. Just first off, I’m wondering if you could spend a minute on China and your outlook for that region going forward. I believe there are a couple of government stimulus programs there that could be rolling off in some of your end-markets. So I’m wondering if there is any reason to think that that dynamic could offset some of your core organic growth in that region next year?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again there is lots and lots of noise in the press in terms of what’s going to happen in China, what are they going to do in terms of addressing inflation, what’s the next five years plan. Obviously, to-date, we are in a very, very strong position and
componenttext:
Again there is lots and lots of noise in the press in terms of what’s going to happen in China, what are they going to do in terms of addressing inflation, what’s the next five years plan. Obviously, to-date, we are in a very, very strong position and have made a big investment.
What I’m going to do is ask each of the Presidents to make a comment. We all spend enormous amount of time in China. We have, in fact just recently met with our local teams and we’re obviously quite confident of the guidance that we just gave. But I’ll start with Ron and have him talk given how much of his business is shifted Asia, and then have Nick and Mike, give comments in each of their respective markets.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, 40% of our overall business roughly is in Asia right now and again, we continue to see that outpace the rest of the world and for us to be very, very strong and growing our overall percentage of business that is in Asia. Just as the ma
componenttext:
Well, first of all, 40% of our overall business roughly is in Asia right now and again, we continue to see that outpace the rest of the world and for us to be very, very strong and growing our overall percentage of business that is in Asia. Just as the matter of fact put a new sales manager in place who will add tremendously to the region, but again we’re very, very excited with what we have there.
Different technology that is flowing in the TDS-CDMA area, which is the 3G technology is adding a lot to our overall business and we’re also seeing some activity in R&D on the 4G side. But again our business in China is exceptionally strong and we continue to expand where we’re adding 30 new field engineers and application engineers to keep up with the revenue growth and as I meant continually to expand the structure in China. So, we continue to outpace the market growth.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the Life Science a couple of comments. First comment is we’ve really been seeing tremendous growth in Asia in general and in China and while it’s not quite the dominant sector, it is one that would have dominance probably this quarter. The additio
componenttext:
For the Life Science a couple of comments. First comment is we’ve really been seeing tremendous growth in Asia in general and in China and while it’s not quite the dominant sector, it is one that would have dominance probably this quarter. The addition of Varian actually gives us a great opportunity. They were not heavily penetrated in Life Science in terms of the China mix. So, we have an opportunity to accelerate that penetration.
The general China market comment you made, you’re right, we’re rolling to a new five-year plan and you’re right there was some extraordinary stimulus at the end of this five-year plan, which is ending this year. But what we’re seeing so far is that at least in the Life Science and healthcare markets, I think Michael echo comments and so when I ask to him, he can. But in the Life Science and healthcare markets, we’re seeing strong sentiment coming in the five-year plan that’s rolling out now to continue strong investment there. So, we’re very optimistic that not only are we positioned properly, but the market itself is very robust.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to build on Nick’s comments, what we’re seeing on the Chemical Analysis side, short-term commentary, business remains quite robust in China. One of the major drivers for our performance in the recently completed quarter, your question is really a
componenttext:
Just to build on Nick’s comments, what we’re seeing on the Chemical Analysis side, short-term commentary, business remains quite robust in China. One of the major drivers for our performance in the recently completed quarter, your question is really around the long-term outlook. We remain quite positive in terms of the outlook for China.
I know there is a question about the five-year plan as you alluded to. But we just hosted a very large delegation here in the area of food safety and it’s very clear to myself that this will continue to be an area of major interest of the Chinese government, their major funding and the great opportunity for Agilent with our expanded portfolio.

componenttext: And then just secondly on pricing, I know there was a little discussion there earlier and I’m wondering if there was any sort of sequential change that you saw in the pricing environment this quarter and then maybe for next year, what your assumptions are for contribution for pricing. It’s sounded like you didn’t have much baked in?

componenttext: No, we’re pricing less or certainly dramatically changes in the economy pricing won’t be a factor in our performance next year.

componenttext: And then just the last question I would ask would be on maybe couple of those product-specific items. Your thoughts on the market share dynamics that you’re seeing in your Life Science business from mass spec in HPLC, you’ve added some great new products there. I’m just wondering how they are doing? Just secondly on 3G, there is some talk about how network demand is progressing. I’m just wondering where you’re seeing the most strength regionally?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess all that you guys calculate specific share but I’ll make a couple of quick comments on the mass spec and on the LC products. We believe that we’ve launched a Triple Quadruple instrument with highest performance in the market. We believe that w
componenttext:
I guess all that you guys calculate specific share but I’ll make a couple of quick comments on the mass spec and on the LC products. We believe that we’ve launched a Triple Quadruple instrument with highest performance in the market. We believe that we’re pretty close to the high edge, if not at the high edge, in our Q-TOF product. We are doing very well in our Single Quad products. Again we think that’s a technology play. So, our expectations on ramp to volume are about our plans and we’re very pleased with that, and we believe we are strongly outgrowing the market in terms of those products.
On LC, we have quoted you a 21% growth for the quarter and we believe that that’s probably almost 4X the market on instruments, somehow between 3X and 4X. So, there is some market expansion in terms of UHPLC, there is some market expansion in terms of new biologic entity for mass spectrometry, but you can do the math against our peers and competitors and get a share view.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to our new product and what’s going on with share again, as Nick mentioned, I will let you calculate the share, but just give a couple of stats on the digital side. Our orders were up 76% this quarter and for the full fiscal year our orders
componenttext:
With regards to our new product and what’s going on with share again, as Nick mentioned, I will let you calculate the share, but just give a couple of stats on the digital side. Our orders were up 76% this quarter and for the full fiscal year our orders were up over 50% for oscilloscopes. So, that’s I think will be easy to see how we’re doing there.
If you look on the wireless side and look at our network analyzers, spectrum analyzers and signal sources which play into that, the growth rates were all over 40% up to 58% during this last quarter. So, we’re seeing very solid healthy growth due to the strength of our portfolio, and in many cases you can see we are taking share.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 Agilent Technologies Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Keisha, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to yo
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2010 Agilent Technologies Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Keisha, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Ms. Alicia Rodriguez, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keisha, and welcome, everyone, to Agilent's Fourth Quarter Conference Call for Fiscal Year 2010. With me are Agilent's President and CEO, Bill Sullivan; as well as Senior Vice President and CFO, Didier Hirsch. Joining in our Q&A will be the P
componenttext:
Thank you, Keisha, and welcome, everyone, to Agilent's Fourth Quarter Conference Call for Fiscal Year 2010. 
With me are Agilent's President and CEO, Bill Sullivan; as well as Senior Vice President and CFO, Didier Hirsch. Joining in our Q&A will be the Presidents of Agilent's Electronic Measurement, Life Sciences and Chemical Analysis Groups: Ron Nersesian, Nick Roelofs and Mike McMullen. 
After my comments, Bill will give his perspective on the quarter and the overall market environment. Didier will then follow with the review of financial results. And after Didier's comments, we will open the lines and take your questions.
In case you haven't had a chance to review our press release, you can find it on our website at www.investor.agilent.com. Please note that the business segment financial tables are in the schedules that accompany the press release. 
We are also providing further information to supplement today's discussion. After you log on to our webcast module from our website, please click on the link for supporting materials. There, you will find additional information, such as our revenue break outs and historical financial information for Agilent's continuing operations.
Also in accordance with SEC Regulation G, if during this conference call we use any non-GAAP financial measures, you will find on our website the required reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial metrics. Additionally, I'd like to remind you that we will make forward-looking statements about the future financial performance of the company. These involve risks and uncertainties that could cause Agilent's results to differ materially from management's current expectations.
As a result, we encourage you to look at the company's most recent filings with the SEC to get a more complete picture of all the factors at work. The forward-looking statements, including our guidance provided today during the call, are only valid as of this date, and the company assumes no obligation to update such statements as we move throughout the current quarter.
Now let me turn the call over to Bill for his comments.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alicia, and hello, everyone. Agilent's latest results continue to build on the strong momentum that we have seen throughout fiscal 2010. There are three major things that have emerged. One, we have successfully completed the transformation of Agil
componenttext:
Thanks, Alicia, and hello, everyone. Agilent's latest results continue to build on the strong momentum that we have seen throughout fiscal 2010. There are three major things that have emerged. One, we have successfully completed the transformation of Agilent. Two, the Varian integration is going exceedingly well. Three, we are benefiting from strong organic growth as a result of the regional sales support expansion and technology investments we have made.
Fourth quarter orders of $1.7 billion were up 32% year-over-year, while revenues of $1.6 billion were up 36% from a year ago. Note that these numbers include the results of the Varian acquisition. Without the Varian acquisition and recent divestitures, orders and revenues were up 23% and 26%, respectively.
In addition to the top line growth, our Q4 non-GAAP earnings were more than doubled to $228 million or $0.65 per share from a year ago. Agilent's fourth quarter revenue growth was strong across all regions. Excluding acquisitions and divestitures, the Americas were up 23% year-over-year, Europe was up 13% and Asia-Pacific was up 38%. 
On November 1, we successfully reached a major milestone in the integration of the Varian acquisition. This includes combining all Agilent and Varian legal entities and moving Varian employees to Agilent's pay and benefits. Agilent and Varian now appears as one single company to our customers. We now have one website, unified call centers, a combined field organization and a single service and support process for our customers. Quotations, orders and invoices are all common for Agilent and Varian products. 
Moving forward, our priorities to continue to drive revenue and cost synergies, as well as to drive technology sharing between the divisions and business groups. We now believe that we will achieve $100 million in net savings. This is inclusive of $10 million of additional R&D we are investing in Varian technologies, as well as our increased investments in service and support.
From a market perspective, our fourth quarter results saw continued strength in our key markets and geographies. In our Chemical Analysis business, we saw sustained growth across all market segments. Q4 revenues of $389 million were up 73% over last year, up 17% excluding Varian. Operating margin, including Varian, was 22%. The energy and petrochemical markets continue to recover, while food and environmental markets remained strong around the world. 
From a product perspective, our new product introductions of GC/MS, ICP-MS and GC Triple-Quad continue to drive strong interest in growth in food and environmental applications. In the 5975 transportable MSD [Mass Spectometry Detector], which was introduced to PCOM is getting significant interest from government sector. 
In our Life Science business, revenues of $431 million were up 35% over last year. Not including Varian and the high core divestiture, Life Science revenue is in an all-time high, growing 17% compared to Q4 2009. Operating margin including Varian was 14%.
Academic and government revenues grew 31% over the last year on an organic basis. The academic market remains solid, particularly in light of U.S. stimulus and growth in China. We saw 14% year-over-year organic growth in Pharma and Biotech. The market continues to face a paradigm shift as companies continue to restructure, outsource and move to low-cost locations. We are well positioned to take advantage of the Pharma shift to developing countries.
From a product perspective, platform growth was strong across the board, with Life Sciences platforms all growing by double digits year-over-year. LC revenues led by our 1290 and 1260 products were up 21% year-over-year. LC/MS and Genomics, including our SureSelect products, continue to perform very well. 
In Electronic Measurement, revenues of $764 million were up 23% from year ago. Excluding the Network Solutions divestitures, revenues grew 35%. Operating margin was 20%. Aerospace and defense was up 60%, while revenues from industrial, computer and semiconductor customers grew 43% from a year ago. Electronic industry growth continues to be strong and outpaced general economic growth. Key drivers continue to be business investment and emerging economy expansion.
Excluding the Network Solutions divestitures, communication revenues were up 41% over last year. 3G technologies continue to dominate spending in both wireless manufacturing and wireless R&D. LTE investment is focused on R&D and continues to grow. Geographically, all regions saw a year-over-year increase led by Asia, which contributed half of Electronic Measurements dollar growth. 
From a platform perspective, we have our strongest product line up in years. Our PNA-X Network Analyzers, PXA Signal Analyzers and PSG Signal Generators, all continue to drive growth and outperform our competitors. 
Our scope business was up 39% year-over-year. We are continuing to gaining share with our high-performance oscilloscopes, led by the success of our Infineon X series . And we introduced 48 new module instrument products in Q4. 
Moving forward, we continue to see numerous market opportunities, and we believe Agilent is in a strong position to capitalize on them. There are four major areas where we differentiate ourselves. First is our market reach and customer trust, where we continue to vest in customer service and support. We are paying special attention to supporting our continued growth in Asia. 
Second is our technology leadership. While we currently have the leading technology in every one of our core platforms, we will maintain R&D investment 11% of revenue in fiscal year '11. We continue to believe that our above-industry average R&D investment will maintain our technology leadership across all major products. In addition, it will fund such strategic initiatives such as Life Science operational surveillance and nanotechnology. We plan to release many exciting new products in 2011.
Third is our scale and scope. We currently have among the lowest instrument cost of sales in the industry. At the same time, we maintain our stellar reputation for quality and reliability. Our global manufacturing capability is second to none. As we move into 2011, we plan to drive substantial improvements in cost of sales across all Varian portfolio, as well as improve cost of sales across the balance of our analytical product portfolio. 
For example, we have recently opened our new LC/MS factory in Singapore. We plan to transfer RF console manufacturing for NMR to Penang [Penang, Malaysia]. We will shut down our Walnut Creek facility and consolidate it with other Agilent facilities. We will move machine tooling out of our Australia facility. And we will continue to leverage the scale of our procurement of logistics operations.
The fourth way we differentiate ourselves is our team. Our 18,500 employees remain focused externally on our customers and our market opportunities. We're in a strong position moving into the new fiscal year. 
For the first quarter of 2011, we expect revenues in the range of $1.53 billion to $1.55 billion. Non-GAAP earnings are expected to be in the range of $0.55 to $0.57 per share. For the full fiscal year 2011, we expect revenue to range from $1.6 billion to $6.3 billion and non-GAAP earnings of $2.30 to $2.50 per share. 
Thank you for being on the call. And now I'll turn it over to Didier.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I'll start by providing additional color on our fourth quarter results and then comment on our outlook for Q1 and the new fiscal year. And all my comments will refer to non-GAAP figures. So starting with Q4 r
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I'll start by providing additional color on our fourth quarter results and then comment on our outlook for Q1 and the new fiscal year. And all my comments will refer to non-GAAP figures. 
So starting with Q4 results. As Bill mentioned, Agilent delivered a very solid fourth quarter performance. Orders of $1.7 billion were up 32% from one year ago, both in dollars and local currency, with Asia Pacific up 40%, the Americas up 27% and Europe up 31%. 
Orders grew 23% on an organic basis. Revenues of $1.6 billion were up 36% in dollars and local currency from one year ago or 26% on an organic basis. All three business segments generated strong double-digit revenue growth, both in total and organically.
Geographic revenues on an organic basis increased 38% in Asia Pacific and grew 23% in the Americas and 30% in Europe. Organic revenue growth in China was 37%, while India revenue grew 31%. 
Now moving to the income statement. Fourth quarter non-GAAP operating profit of $303 million improved $153 million from one year ago on a $417 million increase in revenues at 37% operating margin incremental. Excluding Varian, the year-over-year operating margin incremental was 63%, with all three segments delivering very sound operating margin incrementals on an organic basis. 
The story of this outstanding year-over-year performance remains the same as last quarter, as we saw strong top line revenue growth coupled with a market-lowered cost structure that was created through our restructuring programs completed earlier in the year. Currency had minimal impact on any of the income statement line items.
Now turning to the individual income statement line item. Fourth quarter gross margins of the 55.3% were essentially flat from last year. Excluding Varian, gross margins of 57.1% improved by 1.5 points over last year. We did recognize a few nonrecurring costs in Q4 that reduced gross margin by about 0.5 points.
Fourth quarter operating expense increased $73 million year-over-year, primarily due to the Varian acquisition. Weight restoration and higher variable and incentive pay were offset by restructuring savings. Operating profit of $303 million more than doubled from the same period last year. Agilent's fourth quarter operating margin was 19%, an increase of six points from one year ago and our highest operating margin performance ever.
Net other income and expense declined $12 million from last year due to higher interest expenses. However, we plan to retire the $1.5 billion World Trade debt on December 1, 2 months earlier than planned, which will reduce our interest expense by over $2 million per month starting in December.
Moving to taxes. Note that our non-GAAP tax rate will remain at 19% in fiscal year 2011. We expect our non-GAAP tax rate to further decline to 18% in fiscal year '12 in conjunction with the completion of the Varian integration. Non-GAAP net income of $228 million or $0.65 per share compares to $111 million and $0.32 per share one year ago. Both quarterly earnings per share and full-year EPS of $2 are record high for Agilent.
Now turning to the cash flow and the balance sheet. We continue to demonstrate discipline in asset management. Inventory days on hand of 92 days were five days better than one year ago. Receivables days sales outstanding increased three days from one year ago to 49 days due to Varian higher days sales outstanding.
Total cash from operations was $367 million, an increase of $164 million from one year ago. During the quarter, we received $37 million from employees stock programs and repurchased $51 million worth of shares. Year-to-date, we have received $301 million and repurchased $410 million. We will continue the present buyback program intended to keep the basic outstanding share count at 346 million shares. This anti-diluted share buyback program will utilize about $120 million in cash in fiscal year '11. 
Based on the present stock price, you should assume $356 million diluted shares throughout fiscal year '11. With regards to net cash, we finished the quarter with net cash of $598 million. 
Now turning to the fiscal year 2011 outlook. You will recall that last quarter, we provided two scenarios that bracketed the range of Agilent estimate with the revenue range of $5.9 billion on the low end and $6.2 billion on the high end and EPS of $2.15 to $2.50, which was based on 352 million diluted shares. 
We are now increasing our fiscal year '11 revenue guidance range to $6.1 billion to $6.3 billion and EPS of $2.30 to $2.50 based on 356 million diluted shares. With this new guidance, we are raising the low end of the revenue range by $200 million and $0.15 for EPS and the high end of the revenue range by $100 million with no charge in EPS. 
We are holding to the high-end of the EPS range as more than half of the projected revenue increases due to currency changes that provide minimal incremental operating profit. In addition, we're selectively investing about $20 million on revenue-generating projects and activities. Finally, the $4 million share increase in diluted shares reduces EPS by $0.03.
You will note that the midpoint of our revenue guidance, $6.2 billion, translate into 13% year-over-year growth or 8% growth in an organic basis. The midpoint of our EPS guidance, $2.40, translate into 20% growth over our fiscal year '10 EPS of $2. There are few other items to keep in mind, as you update your models for fiscal year '11. 
Annual salary increases will be effective December 1, 2010. Stock-based compensation will be about $73 million compared to $66 million in fiscal year '10. And as we front-load the recognition of stock-based compensation, the Q1 expense would be about $26 million. 
Third, we expect operating cash flow of approximately $950 million and capital expenditures of about $150 million, which yields free cash flow of approximately $800 million. Fourth, we distribute our variable pay and incentive pay in Q1 and Q3. Hence, Q2 and Q4 are seasonally higher cash flow quarters. And fifth, depreciation and amortization are projected to be $150 million for the fiscal year. 
Finally, moving to the guidance for our first quarter. We expect Q1 revenues of $1,530,000,000 to $1,550,000,000 million, an EPS of $0.55 to $0.57. At the midpoint, year-over-year revenue growth will be 27% or 16% on an organic basis. The midpoint of our EPS guidance corresponds to a year-over-year EPS growth of 47%. 
As you consider the projected decline in EPS on Q4 to Q1, you will want to keep in mind the impact of the December salary increase, front-loading of stock-based compensation and the increase in payroll taxes due to the disbursement of our second half fiscal year '10 variable and incentive pay. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Alicia for the Q&A.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: And then if Nick Roelofs is there, how are you thinking about Pharma in 2011? Obviously, there's been a rebound but a lot of pain is still on the tape for the therapeutics company. So I would love to hear your perspectives on Pharma in '11?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, thanks for the question. Given our portfolio, we're still seeing the same dynamic, which is investment is lighting up in places like India, Korea. In fact, we were a little bit positively surprised this quarter at Pharma's strength in the U.S. Europ
componenttext: John, thanks for the question. Given our portfolio, we're still seeing the same dynamic, which is investment is lighting up in places like India, Korea. In fact, we were a little bit positively surprised this quarter at Pharma's strength in the U.S. Europe is going to remain soft. If you dig underneath that, what you see is discontinued transformation of MCE to MDE. Plus the surprises we're seeing in the U.S. are really a recycle of the replacement markets. So that's starting. And I think we're going to see replacement in GA countries from big Pharma on top of our natural trend that we've been talking about for several quarters. So we think it's going to be pretty good. You saw a 14% number this quarter. This was a hot quarter. And we think it's going to be a pretty good year for us in our space in Pharma.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: Bill, if we look at the capital deployment scenarios in FY '11, is it reasonable to assume that if there's no M&A coming in the second half of '11 that, that buyback number could be higher than kind of the base case assumption of $120 million?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, as Didier said, I think you should assume the guidance that we have given. Our top priority right now is to pay back the World Trade debt that will drive EPS growth. The big issue we have is the continued repatriation of cash back into the U.S. And
componenttext: Again, as Didier said, I think you should assume the guidance that we have given. Our top priority right now is to pay back the World Trade debt that will drive EPS growth. The big issue we have is the continued repatriation of cash back into the U.S. And so obviously, if the environment changes or just the normal course of business that we can get more cash in the U.S., one might consider that. But right now, I would assume for 2011 that we'll pay off the debt and maintain the share count, as Didier outlined.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: In terms of costs, I'm going to have Ron make a comment on this because he is, by far, the bigger user of components. Overall, though, the component shortage is clearly subsiding. And that the availability of components has been better. And of course, if you look at our cost of sales, as Didier x Varian, we're obviously able to compensate for that. But I'll let Ron give some commentary just on availability and pricing.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you're looking at our gross margin for the last year, we had actually the highest gross margin that we've seen in the last decade, in fiscal year '10 at 58%. So overall, our gross margin is doing very well. We do not see material price inflation. Our c
componenttext: If you're looking at our gross margin for the last year, we had actually the highest gross margin that we've seen in the last decade, in fiscal year '10 at 58%. So overall, our gross margin is doing very well. We do not see material price inflation. Our cost of goods cost-reduction programs our offsetting that. And we do not anticipate there to be a big issue.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just to conclude, the work that we are going to do on improving the Varian cost of sales, I think, is just going to overwhelm any increase of component part cost. In terms of your second question, again, the low end at the guidance that we gave at $6.
componenttext: And just to conclude, the work that we are going to do on improving the Varian cost of sales, I think, is just going to overwhelm any increase of component part cost. In terms of your second question, again, the low end at the guidance that we gave at $6.1 billion, we have enormous momentum going into 2011. Our backlog has grown. The order rate of $1.7 billion in Q4, again, have continued to have a very solid greater than one book to bill. And so the big wild card is the second half of 2011. We have assumed in this plan that growth in the U.S., in Europe, in Japan would be at best 2%, could be lower than that aggregately. We still believe that there is opportunity in emerging markets, obviously, China and India. We also see opportunity in Latin America, driven by Brazil, and continued growth through some of the other countries in Southeast Asia. So we think we have a very balanced portfolio, coupled with that, is that we are going to maintain our position as the technology leader. And I still believe that almost any scenario that customers will be able to pay a for differential measurement solutions.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
