headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Will, this is back, of course, to your first question. Really in the Varian research product business, first, we saw the strongest orders and the strongest revenue in history of that business. And I think the orders is a compliment to the fact that the cu
componenttext: Will, this is back, of course, to your first question. Really in the Varian research product business, first, we saw the strongest orders and the strongest revenue in history of that business. And I think the orders is a compliment to the fact that the customer base is seeing us invest in sales guys and service guys and seeing that team starting to get trained now that we're two quarters in. And they have confidence that we will really be there for them to service. They obviously can't yet see the investments we're doing in R&D. But that's the other side of the same equation, which is we have real confidence that we can put some momentum in the cost of goods of the product, both with breakthrough technology from the RF capabilities of EMG. But also, as Bill mentioned, we're moving our console to be close to, actually on top of the EMG manufacturing site in Penang. And that will give us cost of goods as well as proximity to accelerate getting those R&D improvements into the product mix.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of government, and again, I'll have Mike make comment about forensics environment, there's a classic one for the government. But from the DoD perspective, which by far is the biggest government, our growth rate was 17% year-over-year, 8%
componenttext: And then in terms of government, and again, I'll have Mike make comment about forensics environment, there's a classic one for the government. But from the DoD perspective, which by far is the biggest government, our growth rate was 17% year-over-year, 8% sequentially. So aerospace and defense business continues to do quite well. That's obvious. And I've talked about this quite publicly, is one of the bigger concerns that we have had in terms of will there be a major cutback in the U.S., given that's half the market. And to date, we continue to do very well with leading products into that, the DoD budget for next year, in fact, as I believe, up 4%. And we continue to do well in other countries outside the U.S. So Mike, you may want to comment on the environmental and the forensics, which is another, I believe, government purchased commodities.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Will, just to kind of pin the story here from a chemical analysis perspective, we've actually seen continued strength in the government sector, both in U.S., China and other emerging countries. I think you saw in our announcement, for example, some of the
componenttext: Will, just to kind of pin the story here from a chemical analysis perspective, we've actually seen continued strength in the government sector, both in U.S., China and other emerging countries. I think you saw in our announcement, for example, some of the success we've had with a recently introduced transportable GC/MS product. Just one more indication of the willingness to invest in areas that are quite of an interest in the public sector, whether it be food safety and whether it be the environmental hazards that may exist in their local community. So we've actually seen continued strength from a government level of funding throughout this quarter and expect to see that continue into FY '11. By the way, the state forensic level of spending in the U.S. has been depressed. And we're not really counting on a major recovery there. But overall, the government-driven spending in our business has been solid and we continue to expect it to be robust.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Groberg representing Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Groberg representing Macquarie.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you explain why the share count is going up? I thought you said you were going to try and keep it flat but you're saying it's up $4 million. Is that just sort of a reflection of the share price?
componenttext: Did you explain why the share count is going up? I thought you said you were going to try and keep it flat but you're saying it's up $4 million. Is that just sort of a reflection of the share price?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly. We are keeping the basic share count outstanding at 346 million shares. This one, we really controlled. The diluted share count, we don't control because it's very much impacted by the share price. And with the significant increase in the sh
componenttext: Yes, exactly. We are keeping the basic share count outstanding at 346 million shares. This one, we really controlled. The diluted share count, we don't control because it's very much impacted by the share price. And with the significant increase in the share price now, we are seeing it at $35, $36. We computed that outdated share count would be about, what I've said, 356 million shares. Even at the basic outstanding share counts, which we control, will remain at 346 million, which is the intent of the program.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there some rule of thumb, like if your stock price were at like $40 instead of $35? What does that do to the diluted share count?
componenttext: Is there some rule of thumb, like if your stock price were at like $40 instead of $35? What does that do to the diluted share count?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, our diluted share count this year has been between 350 million and now it's 356 million. So you can map that to the change in the share price. But it could change over time depending on the, obviously, when those stock options are best and t
componenttext: Well, I mean, our diluted share count this year has been between 350 million and now it's 356 million. So you can map that to the change in the share price. But it could change over time depending on the, obviously, when those stock options are best and things like that. But yes, that's about that. I mean, our share price has been between, what, $27 and $36, and our diluted share count between 350 million and 356 million.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, if you can -- I don't know, Bill, you probably won't answer this question, but you're doing 20% operating margins in EM right now. It looks like you still see continued momentum in that business. Any update in terms of kind of the operating mode
componenttext: And then, if you can -- I don't know, Bill, you probably won't answer this question, but you're doing 20% operating margins in EM right now. It looks like you still see continued momentum in that business. Any update in terms of kind of the operating model for that business?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're on a lot of momentum. And I'll have Ron answer your question.
componenttext: We're on a lot of momentum. And I'll have Ron answer your question.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We obviously, feel very, very comfortable with the model that we have outlaid. And we've been outperforming with the 58% incremental during this past year. With the cost structure that we have, we are maintaining what we had planned and we are capturing u
componenttext: We obviously, feel very, very comfortable with the model that we have outlaid. And we've been outperforming with the 58% incremental during this past year. With the cost structure that we have, we are maintaining what we had planned and we are capturing upside. For instance in the oscilloscope market, we had mentioned that we had 39% revenue growth. But if we look at the last quarter, our order growth was over 70%. We also had record-high high-performance scopes, record-high sampling scopes. All regions were over 50% growth. And we had record-high unit growth. So there's a lot of things that is helping us drive great incrementals in the business and over 40% incrementals as we go forward. But we feel very comfortable with the guidance that we've given that we'll be able to meet or exceed that guidance.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again EMG, as you know, is targeted to have the high end of our increment, a 30% to 40% increment. And as Ron just said, absolutely committed to do that and all the incentives are in place to reward that result.
componenttext: Again EMG, as you know, is targeted to have the high end of our increment, a 30% to 40% increment. And as Ron just said, absolutely committed to do that and all the incentives are in place to reward that result.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow-up on EM on the up front, order growth. Are you saying and we heard previously that you've been doing some discussions in that business that there is a potential for a big replacement cycle. We're talking about on the LC side a lot
componenttext: If I could just follow-up on EM on the up front, order growth. Are you saying and we heard previously that you've been doing some discussions in that business that there is a potential for a big replacement cycle. We're talking about on the LC side a lot but maybe not as much on the EM side, just given the advances that are being made and just technological requirements, whether it be in some of the optics or in some of the buses and so. Is the growth just a rebound still? Or are you seeing like a replacement, that you need new oscilloscopes that have higher speeds, et cetera? And that there needs to be a replacement that goes on to be able to keep up with the demands?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The oscilloscope market, in particular the real-time oscilloscope market, really continues to grow because there continues to be new technology and new bus speeds that demand higher and higher speeds as the bandwidth needs are insatiable. So that will alw
componenttext: The oscilloscope market, in particular the real-time oscilloscope market, really continues to grow because there continues to be new technology and new bus speeds that demand higher and higher speeds as the bandwidth needs are insatiable. So that will always continue to go on, and we've seen that continuously. On the overall wireless area, we're seeing the smartphone growth really explode where we saw over 70% unit growth for the industry. And we've also seen the adoption rate of 3G phones continue to increase to about 24%. So there's a lot of talk about the next replacement generation, which is LTE or fourth generation. That is happening, but as Bill mentioned, that's mostly in R&D. And we're seeing some infrastructure growth, although you won't see a lot of infrastructure growth until 2011 and more particularly, 2012 and 2013. So the fundamentals are very good, but it's not going to be an instantaneous stair step up.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken representing Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Muken representing Deutsche Bank.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Vijar in for Ross. I just wanted to dig in on the defense part. There was a press article out there in Wall Street Journal yesterday as part of their Deficit Introduction Commissions report, talking about maybe $100 billion reduction in defense bu
componenttext: This is Vijar in for Ross. I just wanted to dig in on the defense part. There was a press article out there in Wall Street Journal yesterday as part of their Deficit Introduction Commissions report, talking about maybe $100 billion reduction in defense budgets. Just to be sure, I mean, on the defense part, the way to think about it is aerospace, defense and surveillance equipment is where the incremental growth is coming in. So in general, a headline news like $100 billion reduction does not necessarily translate to a weakness on the defense side, right?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, and I'll have Ron make a comment about some of the sectors, particularly, operational surveillance as you just referenced. Again, I've been very open about it last year. If you look at what the risk is, the risk is will there be a substantial
componenttext: Absolutely, and I'll have Ron make a comment about some of the sectors, particularly, operational surveillance as you just referenced. Again, I've been very open about it last year. If you look at what the risk is, the risk is will there be a substantial cut back in defense spending, given the budget issues in the U.S. To date, that has not happened. The budget for next year has not been cut. That recommendation of $100 million is from the task force, as the President had set up to figure out where are ways that the country can cut back on expenses. My own personal opinion, in the short-term, given the employment issues, not obvious to me that those decision can be made. But what we need to do is make sure that we have the right products for the next-generation radar systems, missile systems that we can make a contribution. And the operational surveillance is it's just a real obvious place where that both parties fully support. So I'll have Ron give you an update on where we are on operational surveillance.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On operational surveillance, we're seeing exceptional growth on the networks side, where there is surveillance on the networks side. And in particular, we've seen over 100% growth during the last year and seen that business move from investment mode to so
componenttext: On operational surveillance, we're seeing exceptional growth on the networks side, where there is surveillance on the networks side. And in particular, we've seen over 100% growth during the last year and seen that business move from investment mode to solid double-digit profitability. We continue to see that segment explode. And even if there is some type of pullback on new programs, overall in defense, we're seeing very healthy business at maintaining existing systems where Agilent's install base and breadth of products is a real strong asset. So we feel very comfortable with the aerospace defense market in general and see some real growth in operational surveillance.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe a quick follow-up in the Life Science segment from Nick. You mentioned that academic segment was strong. Could you sort of just parse out what you're seeing in Europe? And sort of what's been the stimulus impact out there? And maybe some of your
componenttext: And maybe a quick follow-up in the Life Science segment from Nick. You mentioned that academic segment was strong. Could you sort of just parse out what you're seeing in Europe? And sort of what's been the stimulus impact out there? And maybe some of your Genomic, the SureSelect platform and sort of what can we can expect going forward?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the real strength in that academic segment, a lot of that is coming from investment in Asia, just as a comment. But you hit the nail on the head. Two comments of the subtext. One, in Europe, we actually were surprised to see quite a bit of academic sec
componenttext: So the real strength in that academic segment, a lot of that is coming from investment in Asia, just as a comment. But you hit the nail on the head. Two comments of the subtext. One, in Europe, we actually were surprised to see quite a bit of academic sector growth in countries like France, Germany, Switzerland. And that was really nice seeing them spend some of their money to put in infrastructure in the academic sector around Life Science. The big story really is the SureSelect, though. Genome partitioning in front of next-generation DNA sequencing is really catching fire. You're starting to see others see that market opportunity as well. We believe we've got a tremendous technology leadership position there. And we believe, therefore, we have a tremendous position in that market. And that is growing in Europe as well as around the world.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the SureSelect, I mean, we've heard some commercial computers getting in products and just given where stimulus is and what's the expectation? I'm just trying to think second half of '11 and what's the expectations?
componenttext: On the SureSelect, I mean, we've heard some commercial computers getting in products and just given where stimulus is and what's the expectation? I'm just trying to think second half of '11 and what's the expectations?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is a market where you've probably seen this market grow 5x year-over-year as a market. And we're riding waves similar to that growth. So it's just a small nascent market that's now becoming a real piece. I think going forward, you're going to se
componenttext: Yes, this is a market where you've probably seen this market grow 5x year-over-year as a market. And we're riding waves similar to that growth. So it's just a small nascent market that's now becoming a real piece. I think going forward, you're going to see the dollar shifting from the reagent piece that is being spent in next-gen sequencing on the instrument through that genome partitioning. And obviously, a lot of people are going to want to participate. There's a lot of good tools out there. We do think that we have a technically differentiable solution. And by doing partitioning in front of the genome, you effectively reduce the cost of real data coming out of the genome because you can do 1/10 of the genome and effectively reduce the price and get all the data you need.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman representing Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Eastman representing Robert W. Baird.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question for Ron, on the EM side of the business, when you look at, I think in Didier's comment that maybe for fiscal '11, EM would be up in the 10% kind of organic growth range. If you split EM into the two pieces, kind of communications and then all els
componenttext: Question for Ron, on the EM side of the business, when you look at, I think in Didier's comment that maybe for fiscal '11, EM would be up in the 10% kind of organic growth range. If you split EM into the two pieces, kind of communications and then all else for general purpose, a lot of new product flow on the general purpose side, the modular instruments, surveillance and, Bill, you mentioned nanotech. And then on communications, you have kind of this LTE dynamic underplaying. So how do you look at those two pieces of the business relative to that 10% organic growth in fiscal '11? And how much of that might be new product-driven versus end-market recovery?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Richard, we have products that span both the GP market and the communications market, with outside of the divestiture, grew 41% and 32%. And just to give you an idea, if you look at our core platforms, which includes our oscilloscopes, our network analyze
componenttext: Richard, we have products that span both the GP market and the communications market, with outside of the divestiture, grew 41% and 32%. And just to give you an idea, if you look at our core platforms, which includes our oscilloscopes, our network analyzers, spectrum analyzers and signal sources, they're used in both areas with a little bit more biased of high-performance products in the communications segment. They grew 49% this last quarter. And we have spent a lot of time over the last three-plus years refreshing those platforms. In particular, when we look at our network analyzers, we introduced the highest performance network analyzers this last quarter, the quarter before, the highest performance real-time oscilloscopes, and in the past couple of years, spectrum analyzers and signal sources. So we see that the refreshing of our portfolio is something that will drive both segments. Communications, clearly LTE and R&D, as Bill and I had mentioned earlier, will drive things. But there still is very substantial growth in 3G technologies even particularly in China, where we were one of the first ones to jump on the bandwagon of TD-SCDMA, which is the China standard version for 3G. We're seeing some healthy growth from our investments. But we don't see a strong bias, one way or the other, due to the core platforms to span both segments, Richard.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, from the perspective of nanotechnology, some products coming out there, that's been a growth investment area for you. Is that size to the point where you can maybe move the growth needle year-over-year for all of EM?
componenttext: Bill, from the perspective of nanotechnology, some products coming out there, that's been a growth investment area for you. Is that size to the point where you can maybe move the growth needle year-over-year for all of EM?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, and it's just too big from the core. Again, our AFM, or microwave AFM, are continuing to do very well. We introduced the scanning electron microscope bench top version. But again, just given the size of EM, it is not going to move the needle, but some
componenttext: No, and it's just too big from the core. Again, our AFM, or microwave AFM, are continuing to do very well. We introduced the scanning electron microscope bench top version. But again, just given the size of EM, it is not going to move the needle, but someday it will.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, how do you characterize price across the product lines, across the segments? And typically, it takes the form of less discounting, but is price a positive contributor year-over-year?
componenttext: And then just lastly, how do you characterize price across the product lines, across the segments? And typically, it takes the form of less discounting, but is price a positive contributor year-over-year?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, it clearly has been not a negative. I mean, every account has a different story moving forward, given the snapback and the component shortages. It obviously had a short-term favorable impact on pricing just because of some of the deliver issues,
componenttext: I think, it clearly has been not a negative. I mean, every account has a different story moving forward, given the snapback and the component shortages. It obviously had a short-term favorable impact on pricing just because of some of the deliver issues, particularly in EMG. And so as you go into a slower market, one assumes that there will be more pricing pressure. But that really is the strength of Agilent. We do have the best gross margins in the industry. We believe, and that from an instrumentation standpoint, and we have very aggressive programs going into 2011 to improve our cost of sales. So we will be competitive and right now, obviously, not planning for any degrading of our gross margins.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Luscri, representing JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Luscri, representing JP Morgan.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus a little bit more on the gross margin profile in fiscal '11. I get the impression that you've had a great new product thrust over the last couple of quarters. And I wanted to see if we compare the mix of the new products versus old, how
componenttext: I wanted to focus a little bit more on the gross margin profile in fiscal '11. I get the impression that you've had a great new product thrust over the last couple of quarters. And I wanted to see if we compare the mix of the new products versus old, how that impacts gross margin, and then how should we view the Varian cost of good savings as well. So more or less, is the gross margin profile going to be back-end loaded in fiscal '11?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: To answer your questions, the question, is yes. If you look at all of our new products, and again I welcome any of the group presidents to have a comment, typically, our new products are performance leading. And gross the margins go up. And as we have sta
componenttext: To answer your questions, the question, is yes. If you look at all of our new products, and again I welcome any of the group presidents to have a comment, typically, our new products are performance leading. And gross the margins go up. And as we have stated numerous occasions, we have leadership in every one of our major platforms. Offsetting that, of course, we have investment in these initiatives that we try to get to profitability as quickly as we can. The number one task is the Varian product lines. And we have a full-court press to be able to make that happen, to be able to address that. You're well aware of the gross margins at Varian while it was a public company. We have a lot of work to do. But the good news is that we know exactly what needs to get done. The teams are formed. And it's all about executing moving forward. In addition to that, and look at our Life Science business, Nick has already set up our LC/MS manufacturing site at Singapore. We will continue to aggressively balance our manufacturing around the world to ensure that we have very cost-competitive products, not compromise reliability or quality. And of course, we've minimized as a result any currency issues. But the task, number one, is the Varian product lines, secondly, is our continued focus on driving cost down. We just have a world-class team. As you know, we do own our manufacturing. Yes, we outsourced a lot of the PC board assembly and so forth, but we have 100% control. And the result of that is that we can have continued ongoing value add in engineering to be able to drive cost down and have a program in place to ensure that we can get the best prices from our vendors across all of our product portfolios. Nick?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just like to add a little piece of granularity under two comments Bill made. And they're both the same comment, which is the Varian piece that is in Life Science, and I'm sure Mike may want to comment as well. As Bill said it's job one, the rest of the
componenttext: I just like to add a little piece of granularity under two comments Bill made. And they're both the same comment, which is the Varian piece that is in Life Science, and I'm sure Mike may want to comment as well. As Bill said it's job one, the rest of the portfolio, we've had two great years of product launches. But we are still putting a lot of money in R&D. And so on that gross margin side, there's working through the manufacturing structure, those comments are absolutely spot on. But we're also putting real R&D investment, not only in our traditional Agilent portfolio but in the new Varian products. And to the extent that we continue to deliver new different feasible products, we're going to have really nice performance for the customers and that should keep the gross margin high. And we certainly, coming off two years in a row of beating our record of new product launches numerically, I don't think we're done with that kind of cycle.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. And maybe just one further comment from the CAG side relative to this question. I just would re-emphasize some of the points that Bill made earlier. We know how to do this. We have the series of defined actual plans that are being executed r
componenttext: Thanks, Nick. And maybe just one further comment from the CAG side relative to this question. I just would re-emphasize some of the points that Bill made earlier. We know how to do this. We have the series of defined actual plans that are being executed right now. And I think you'll start to see cost come out in FY' '11, such as combining logistic centers, for example, eliminating duplicate infrastructures a little. There's a number of actions that are being taken the right now, and we'll have costs coming out in the next couple of quarters. And then as we turn to products, you will see improved gross margins there as well.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the EM side, our strategy has been to, one, move more of our business from manufacturing to our R&D, which have higher margins; and two, focus on high-performance products; and three, add more application software, which has higher gross margins. S
componenttext: And on the EM side, our strategy has been to, one, move more of our business from manufacturing to our R&D, which have higher margins; and two, focus on high-performance products; and three, add more application software, which has higher gross margins. So again, the move to R&D higher performance products where our performance leadership in application software are there to offset any type of pricing issues that we see in the manufacturing space.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the last six years, we have shared that one should assume that over a cycle, for example, that our operating profit, this is again operating profit and not gross margin, is 14%. You should all assume that we are committed to 18% and as you heard, commi
componenttext: In the last six years, we have shared that one should assume that over a cycle, for example, that our operating profit, this is again operating profit and not gross margin, is 14%. You should all assume that we are committed to 18% and as you heard, committed to drive as hard as we can to hopefully someday update that again.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I noticed in your press release that you've indicated that the Varian integration is on track to meet the targeted revenues synergies. And I don't know if I missed what that number is. But along those lines, are you seeing increase traction with new custo
componenttext: I noticed in your press release that you've indicated that the Varian integration is on track to meet the targeted revenues synergies. And I don't know if I missed what that number is. But along those lines, are you seeing increase traction with new customers with the combined entity and how should we view the revenue flow-through over the coming years?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had stated publicly that we thought that revenue would be at $800 million. As you know in Q3, we are behind that, and we had actually had lowered what the run rate was going to be effectively to base on the Q3. What was great about Q4 is that our reven
componenttext: We had stated publicly that we thought that revenue would be at $800 million. As you know in Q3, we are behind that, and we had actually had lowered what the run rate was going to be effectively to base on the Q3. What was great about Q4 is that our revenue, as I said was $193 million and I guess will soon disappear so we won't be reporting this, after we get through one full year. We are very, very close back to the original run rate. And then as you can see from the comments that Nick just made regarding NMR, and Mike, we're quite excited to see if we can in fact drive that. We have not made a statement on what additional opportunities above the $800 million. But as you can tell, Q4 was just a really solid quarter for those product lines and we're quite excited as we move into 2011.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mark Douglass representing Longbow Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mark Douglass representing Longbow Research.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: What are the organic sales assumptions going into '11 at the various segments? Did you mention that?
componenttext: What are the organic sales assumptions going into '11 at the various segments? Did you mention that?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I gave what was consistent with the high end of our guidance, which is in $6.3 billion. And EMG on an organic basis growing 10%, LSG 14% and CG 7%. And that's 10% for Agilent, overall. But you know that the midpoint of our guidance is 8% growth. So you ne
componenttext: I gave what was consistent with the high end of our guidance, which is in $6.3 billion. And EMG on an organic basis growing 10%, LSG 14% and CG 7%. And that's 10% for Agilent, overall. But you know that the midpoint of our guidance is 8% growth. So you need to shave off, somehow, two percentage points from some of those. Mostly in the low end of our guidance, probably I would take away a little bit more on the EMG side depending on the micro-economic conditions.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's all organic?
componenttext: And that's all organic?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have any currency based on this?
componenttext: Do you have any currency based on this?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: All of our guidance is based on the actions rates as of the beginning of our fiscal year.
componenttext: All of our guidance is based on the actions rates as of the beginning of our fiscal year.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: From the $100 million savings in Varian at the step that up now. How did those savings spread out over the next couple of years? And is it split basically between how the revenue split between the two segments, are you're going to get more is more lion sh
componenttext: From the $100 million savings in Varian at the step that up now. How did those savings spread out over the next couple of years? And is it split basically between how the revenue split between the two segments, are you're going to get more is more lion share of the savings, that is possible, as we look forward?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s basically into three buckets. One we call our global infrastructure, and that will be done in our fiscal year 2011. This is again on the corporate functions that are being combined. Some, of course, you have already seen this is a result of the con
componenttext: It’s basically into three buckets. One we call our global infrastructure, and that will be done in our fiscal year 2011. This is again on the corporate functions that are being combined. Some, of course, you have already seen this is a result of the condition of the company and executive team in Varian essentially leaving the company. From there, the first orders disputed by revenue but the buyers will be on LSG, the NMRs, where we have the biggest cost of sales opportunity. And as we have said, we will implement this over the next few years and it's all about our ability to execute to transfer products and get the new products into the system, and it’s about time. But I’m very, very pleased with the progress both Mike and Nick had made in terms of addressing that. And again the alignment with all our 3,000 new employees. They’re very excited about both the opportunities in investment and also the, understanding the responsibility that we need to improve our gross margins as fast as we can. But I would first order, do it by revenue slight biased to LSG, and assume this over the next couple of years.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it quite fair to assume that it's more front-end loaded the next three years?
componenttext: Is it quite fair to assume that it's more front-end loaded the next three years?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, the manufacturing will be back-end loaded just because of the qualifications. The global infrastructure cost will be front-end loaded.
componenttext: No, the manufacturing will be back-end loaded just because of the qualifications. The global infrastructure cost will be front-end loaded.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro representing Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Isaac Ro representing Goldman Sachs.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are a couple of government stimulus programs that could be rolling off in some of your end-markets, so I'm wondering if there is any reason to think that, that dynamic could offset some of your core organic growth in that region next year?
componenttext: There are a couple of government stimulus programs that could be rolling off in some of your end-markets, so I'm wondering if there is any reason to think that, that dynamic could offset some of your core organic growth in that region next year?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, there’s lots and lots of noise in the press in terms of what's going to happen in China, what are they going to do in terms of addressing inflation, what’s the next five-year plan. Obviously, today, we're in a very, very strong position and hav
componenttext: Again, there’s lots and lots of noise in the press in terms of what's going to happen in China, what are they going to do in terms of addressing inflation, what’s the next five-year plan. Obviously, today, we're in a very, very strong position and have made a big investment. And what I'm going to do is ask each of the Presidents to make a comment. We've all spent enormous amount of time in China. We have, in fact, just recently met with our local teams and we’re, obviously, quite confident of the guidance that we just gave. But I'll start with Ron and have him talk given how much his business has shifted to Asia, and then have Nick and Mike give comments in each of their respective markets.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, 40% of our overall businesses roughly is in Asia right now. And again, we continue to see that outpace the rest of the world, and for us to be very strong and growing our overall percentage of business that is in Asia. We’ve, just a
componenttext: Well, first of all, 40% of our overall businesses roughly is in Asia right now. And again, we continue to see that outpace the rest of the world, and for us to be very strong and growing our overall percentage of business that is in Asia. We’ve, just a matter of fact, put a new sales manager in place who will add tremendously to the region. But again, we're very, very excited with what we have there. Different technology that is flowing in the TDS CDMA area, which is the 3G technology, is adding a lot to our overall business. And we’re also seeing some activity in R&D on the 4G side. But again, our business in China is exceptionally strong and we continue to expand where we’re adding 30 new field engineers and application engineers to keep up with the revenue growth. And as I've mentioned, continuing to expand the structure in China so we continued to outpace the market growth.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the Life Science, couple of comments. First comment is, we’ve really been seeing tremendous growth in Asia in general, and in China. And while it's not quite the dominant sector, it is one that would have dominance probably this quarter. The additio
componenttext: For the Life Science, couple of comments. First comment is, we’ve really been seeing tremendous growth in Asia in general, and in China. And while it's not quite the dominant sector, it is one that would have dominance probably this quarter. The addition of Varian actually is a great opportunity. They were not heavily penetrated in life science in terms of the China mix, and so we have an opportunity to accelerate that penetration. The general China market comment you made, you're right, we’re rolling to a new five-year plan. And you're right, there was an extraordinary stimulus at the end of this five-year plan, which is ending this year. But what we’re seeing so far is that, at least in the life science and healthcare markets -- I think Michael echoed comments and so when I pass to him, he can -- but in the life science and healthcare markets, we’re seeing strong sentiment coming in the five-year plan that's rolling out now to continue strong investment there. And so are we’re very optimistic that not only are we positioned properly, but the market itself is very robust.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to build on Nick's comments, what we’re seeing on the Chemical Analysis side. A short-term commentary, business remains quite robust in China. One of the major drivers of our performance in the recently completed quarter. Your question is really ar
componenttext: Just to build on Nick's comments, what we’re seeing on the Chemical Analysis side. A short-term commentary, business remains quite robust in China. One of the major drivers of our performance in the recently completed quarter. Your question is really around the long-term outlook. We remain quite positive in terms of the outlook for China. I know that there's questions about the five-year plan as you alluded to. But we just hosted a very large delegation here in the area of food safety, and it's very clear to myself that this will continue to be an area of major interest of the Chinese government and a major funding and a great opportunity for Agilent with our expanded portfolio.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, on pricing, I know there was a little discussion there earlier. And I'm wondering if there's any sort of a sequential change that you saw on the pricing environment this quarter? And then maybe for next year, what your assumptions are for contri
componenttext: Secondly, on pricing, I know there was a little discussion there earlier. And I'm wondering if there's any sort of a sequential change that you saw on the pricing environment this quarter? And then maybe for next year, what your assumptions are for contribution from pricing, it sounded like you didn’t have much baked in.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we’re pricing, unless there’s something dramatically changes in the economy, pricing won’t be a factor in our performance next year.
componenttext: No, we’re pricing, unless there’s something dramatically changes in the economy, pricing won’t be a factor in our performance next year.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question I would ask would be on maybe a couple of product specific items.  Your thoughts on the market share dynamics that you're seeing in your Life Science business for Mass Spec and HPOC, I know you’ve had some great new products there. I’m j
componenttext: Last question I would ask would be on maybe a couple of product specific items.  Your thoughts on the market share dynamics that you're seeing in your Life Science business for Mass Spec and HPOC, I know you’ve had some great new products there. I’m just wondering how they're doing. And then just secondly on 3G, there’s some talk there about how network demand is progressing, and I’m just wondering where you're seeing the most strength regionally?

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’ll let you guys calculate specific share. But I'll make a couple of quick comments on the Mass Spec and on the LC products. We believe that we’ve launched a triple quadripolar instrument with the highest performance in the market. We believe that we
componenttext: I’ll let you guys calculate specific share. But I'll make a couple of quick comments on the Mass Spec and on the LC products. We believe that we’ve launched a triple quadripolar instrument with the highest performance in the market. We believe that we’re pretty close to the high edge, if not at the high edge, in our Q-TOF product. We’re doing very, very well in our single quad products, again, we think that’s a technology play. So our expectations on ramp to volume are above our plans, and we’re very pleased that. And we believe we’re strongly outgoing the market in terms of those products. On LC, we’ve quoted you a 21% growth for the quarter, and we believe that that’s probably almost 4x the market on instruments, somewhere between 3x and 4x. So there is some market expansion in terms of UHPLC. There is some market expansion in terms of new biologic entity from mass spectrometry. But you can do the math against our peers and competitors and get a share view.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to our new products and what’s going on with share, again, as Nick has mentioned, I’ll let you calculate the share. But just to give a couple of stats, on the digital side, our orders were up 76% this quarter. And for the full fiscal year
componenttext: With regards to our new products and what’s going on with share, again, as Nick has mentioned, I’ll let you calculate the share. But just to give a couple of stats, on the digital side, our orders were up 76% this quarter. And for the full fiscal year, our orders were the up over 50% for oscilloscopes. So I think that will be easy to see how were doing there. And if you look on the wireless side, and look at other network analyzers, spectrum analyzers and signal sources, which play into that, the growth rates were all over 40%, up to 58% during this last quarter. So we’re seeing very solid healthy growth due to the strength of our portfolio. And in many cases, you can see we are making share.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: With no further questions in the queue, I would now turn the call back over to Alica Rodriguez, Vice President of Investor Relations for closing remarks. You may proceed.
componenttext: With no further questions in the queue, I would now turn the call back over to Alica Rodriguez, Vice President of Investor Relations for closing remarks. You may proceed.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keisha. On behalf of the Agilent management team, I'd like to thank everybody for joining us this morning. If you have any questions, please contact us at Investor Relations. And thank you and good day.
componenttext: Thank you, Keisha. On behalf of the Agilent management team, I'd like to thank everybody for joining us this morning. If you have any questions, please contact us at Investor Relations. And thank you and good day.

headline: Agilent Technologies Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
